{"uri": "2024-08-447907930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:54:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:54:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:12:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/08/08/carles-puigdemont-ex-catalan-leader-returns-to-spain-after-nearly-7-years-as-a-fugitive/", "title": "Carles Puigdemont, ex-Catalan leader, returns to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "Catalan independence leader and former President Carles Puigdemont addresses supporters after his arrival near the Catalan parliament to attend the investiture debate in Barcelona, Spain, Thursday Aug. 8, 2024. Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who left Spain after organizing an independence referendum in the Spanish northeastern region seven years ago, announced that he plans [...]\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Former Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, who fled Spain after organizing an independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago that was declared illegal, returned to the country on Thursday despite a pending arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont defiantly appeared in Barcelona after traveling from Belgium and made a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters. He faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nAddressing the crowd, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nAfter his speech, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure. Puigdemont's whereabouts weren't known, and police made no immediate comment.\n\nThe 2017 referendum organized by Puigdemont was declared illegal at the time both by Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nThe event was organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont's presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrested.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": {"uri": "8259540338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:26:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/europe/crunch-time-in-spain-as-catalonia-attempts-to-form-new-government", "title": "Crunch time in Spain as Catalonia attempts to form new government", "body": "Catalan separatist leader and candidate of Junts per Catalunya - JxCat political party, Carles Puigdemont (R) raises his fist during a campaign rally in the French southeastern town of Argeles-sur-Mer on May 4, 2024 ahead of the regional election in the Spanish northeastern region of Catalonia. -- AFP file\n\nSpain faces a crucial political week with a key investiture vote expected in Catalonia which exiled Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont has vowed to attend, even though he could be arrested.\n\nThe head of Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's Socialist party in the wealthy northeastern region will undergo the vote in the local assembly after leftist separatist party ERC on Friday voted in favour of backing his efforts to form a new government.\n\nBut the agreement has angered Catalonia's other major separatist party -- Puigdemont's more hardline JxCAT -- and the issue could jeopardise its crucial support for Sanchez's fragile minority government in the national parliament.\n\nNo date has been set for the vote but it is expected at the end of the week.\n\nHere are four things to look out for:\n\nThe Socialists, led locally by Salvador Illa, won the most seats in a regional election in Catalonia in May but fell short of a majority.\n\nThe party picked up 42 of the regional assembly's 135 seats and officially has the backing of the six lawmakers of the far-left party that is part of the Sumar alliance as well as the ERC's 20.\n\nTo form a government, Illa will need at least 68 votes in a first round of voting, or a simple majority in a second round.\n\nBut ERC members approved backing Illa's efforts to form a government by a slim margin of just 53.5 percent and some party lawmakers could rebel and vote against the Socialist candidate.\n\nIf a new Catalan regional government is not formed by August 26, fresh elections will be held in October.\n\nPuigdemont headed the regional government of Catalonia in 2017 when it pushed ahead with an illegal secession referendum that was followed by a short-lived declaration of independence.\n\nHe fled abroad shortly after to avoid prosecution but is still wanted by Spain's justice system. Spain's Supreme Court ruled on July 1 that an amnesty law for Catalan separatists that came into force earlier this year would not fully apply to him.\n\nIn a letter posted on social network X on Saturday, Puigdemont repeated his plans to return to Catalonia for the upcoming investiture vote.\n\n\"I know that my return may entail arrest and imprisonment, who knows for how long,\" he wrote.\n\n\"Just as going into exile was a political decision, returning from exile is also a political decision.\"\n\nPuigdemont's arrest would likely inflame the separatist base and could lead the investiture vote to be called off or the ERC to reconsider its support for Illa.", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khaleej times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8264812838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:44:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:44:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:43:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/spain-catalonia-carles-puigdemont-returns-n86858", "title": "Carles Puigdemont, ex-Catalan leader, returns to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "BARCELONA, Spain -- Former Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, who fled Spain after organizing an independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago that was declared illegal, returned to the country on Thursday despite a pending arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont defiantly appeared in Barcelona after traveling from Belgium and made a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters. He faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain.\n\nAddressing the crowd, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe 2017 referendum organized by Puigdemont was declared illegal at the time both by Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nThe event was organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont's presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrested.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/elections/news/spains-catalonia-to-elect-new-leader-as-ex-leader-puigdemonts-arrest-looms/", "title": "Spain's Catalonia to elect new leader as ex-leader Puigdemont's arrest looms", "body": "The parliament of Spain's Catalonia region is set to elect a new leader this week, although the event may be upstaged by the return of its former leader from self-imposed exile, despite a pending warrant for his arrest.\n\nCarles Puigdemont is the figurehead of hardline separatist party Junts, and led Catalonia between 2016 and 2017 before fleeing Spain following a referendum on independence deemed illegal by the judiciary.\n\nIt remains unclear how he plans to return to the country and enter the regional parliament while evading police.\n\nJordi Turull, secretary-general of Junts, told broadcaster 324 on Tuesday that he would call for the leadership vote to be suspended if Puigdemont is detained, as \"it cannot take place in normal conditions\" without him present.\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, will kick off on Thursday at 10 a.m. local time (0800 GMT), according to the parliamentary speaker.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nA source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nPolitical scientist Toni Rodon of Barcelona's Pompeu Fabra University told Reuters that Puidgemont had possibly decided to come back because of the personal toll of living in exile.\n\n\"The amnesty has changed the game play, and the other strategy he can pursue can be more useful inside the Spanish borders even if he ends up in jail,\" Rodon added.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a \"hybrid coup\", adding \"if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do\".\n\nERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorised to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources.\n\nOfficers were also monitoring the sewer system in case it was used for alternative entry routes.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the building's rooftop by helicopter after it was surrounded by nearly 1,000 anti-austerity activists protesting against budget cuts.", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "EurActiv.com"}, His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nThe event was organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont's presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrest.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Puigdemont could initially be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for {"uri": "2024-08-447803368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "08:24:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T08:24:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:21:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/2024/08/08/carles-puigdemont-ex-catalan-leader-returns-to-spain-after-nearly-7-years-as-a-fugitive/", "title": "Carles Puigdemont, ex-Catalan leader, returns to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "BARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Former Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, who fled Spain after organizing an independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago that was declared illegal, returned to the country on Thursday despite a pending arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont defiantly appeared in Barcelona after traveling from Belgium and made a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters. He faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nAddressing the crowd, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nAfter his speech, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure. Puigdemont's whereabouts weren't known, and police made no immediate comment.\n\nThe 2017 referendum organized by Puigdemont was declared illegal at the time both by Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nThe event was organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont's presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrested.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/politics/catalan-separatist-faces-arrest-on-return-to-spain-c-15627494", "title": "Catalan separatist faces arrest on return to Spain", "body": "Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont is returning after seven years in self-imposed exile to Spain, where he will likely be arrested over his role in the region's 2017 independence bid.\n\nHis arrest and potential imprisonment before he might face trial could unleash fresh turmoil in Catalonia and threaten the fragile Socialist-led coalition ruling Spain, which relies on Puigdemont's hardline Junts party to pass legislation.\n\nTo secure Junts' legislative support for Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's government, Spain's parliament in May approved an amnesty law designed to allow Puigdemont a safe return from Belgium.\n\nThe amnesty aimed to cancel legal proceedings against hundreds of separatists involved in Catalonia's 2017 illegal referendum, but Spain's Supreme Court ruled in July the law did not apply to an embezzlement charge against Puigdemont and upheld an arrest warrant he faces.\n\nStill, Puigdemont said he remained committed to attending the Catalan parliament's session that is due to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont finished second.\n\nThe swearing-in is scheduled for Thursday.\n\nPuigdemont said he would keep his word and be in Barcelona then.\n\n\"I have started the return trip from exile,\" he said in a video posted on X.\n\nHe also said in the video message that his arrest would be illegal and arbitrary.\n\nNeither Puigdemont nor Junts said on Wednesday whether he had already entered Spain.\n\nThursday's session is poised to appoint Socialist Salvador Illa as the new Catalan president, ending more than a decade of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont's supporters plan to welcome him on Thursday morning on a Barcelona boulevard near the regional parliament, setting the stage for a potentially dramatic arrest.\n\nModerate separatist party Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya, currently governing Catalonia, called Puigdemont's return an \"exceptional moment\" and said it would attend the welcoming event.\n\nThat might require a delicate balancing act from the party, which as leader of the regional government is responsible for the {"uri": "2024-08-447230649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "17:53:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T17:53:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T17:01:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/world/article/fugitive-ex-catalan-leader-plans-return-to-spain-19625393.php", "title": "Fugitive ex-Catalan leader plans return to Spain despite threat of arrest over failed secession bid", "body": "BARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain after organizing an illegal independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region seven years ago, announced that he plans to return home on Thursday despite the likelihood of being arrested on his return.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, who fled to Belgium after the breakaway bid in October 2017 quickly collapsed, said Wednesday that he would attend an event organized by his political party Together for Catalonia near Barcelona's regional parliament building hours before a new regional government takes office.\n\nHe did not say when or how he would arrive in Spain. The political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many Puigdemont supporters.\n\nThe Mossos D'Esquadra, the regional police in Catalonia, say that they intend to obey court orders to arrest Puigdemont, if he does return.\n\nIn his announcement made on YouTube, Puigdemont recognized that he \"cannot attend freely\" the scheduled parliamentary session and accused authorities of \"a long persecution\" over the unsuccessful breakaway attempt.\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he said.\n\nPuigdemont's return is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis in Spain.\n\nPuigdemont and his supporters have long taken a confrontational and at times provocative stance toward Spain's central authorities, especially the Madrid-based government.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana.\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday, scheduled shortly after Puigdemont's first planned event and which will take place amid tight security.\n\nPuigdemont, who is wanted on charges of embezzlement during the secession attempt, has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a decadeslong struggle. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nPuigdemont's escape from Spain became the stuff of legend among his followers, and a huge source of embarrassment for Spanish law enforcement. He is a celebrated figurehead for many Catalans who want to break away from the rest of Spain.\n\nEarlier this year, Puigdemont denied that he had hidden in a car trunk to avoid detection while slipping across the border after the referendum. The subsequent legal crackdown landed several of his cohorts in prison until Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez's government pardoned them.", "source": {"uri": "beaumontenterprise.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-448096424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/ex-catalan-leader-puigdemont-a-fugitive-since-2017-returns-to-spain-but-then-he-vanishes/article_0eb7d5bd-8184-5b5f-85d3-17c3b06d6b9f.html", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader Puigdemont, a fugitive since 2017, returns to Spain. But then he vanishes again", "body": "Catalan police mans a checkpoint at a road in the outskirts of Barcelona, Spain, Thursday Aug. 8, 2024. The search for former Catalan president and pro-independence leader Carles Puigdemont by the Mossos d'Esquadra has clogged the main roads, resulting in traffic jams. The officers have activated operation 'cage' to locate the former president, who remains missing after returning to Barcelona following seven years of avoiding arrest for organising an independence referendum in 2017.\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader and fugitive Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated campaigner for Catalan independence who made a sensational return to Spain and an equally sensational getaway from a speech in the city with the alleged help of a local police officer.\n\nThe events took place nearly seven years after Puigdemont fled Spain after a failed independence bid, with an outstanding arrest warrant pending against him.\n\nPuigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on a day that Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president. The 61-year-old initially lived in Belgium after bolting from Spain in 2017, but his latest place of residence wasn't known.\n\nPuigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nCatalan police arrested one of their own officers on charges of aiding Puigdemont's getaway, the force's press office told The Associated Press. No further details were available.\n\nAbout three hours after Puigdemont vanished, Catalan police called off the manhunt without saying why.\n\nThe Catalan police force is called Mossos d'Esquadra and operates separately from Spain's Policia Nacional. At the time of the 2017 ballot, the Spanish government suspended the Mossos' chief and placed the force under investigation for failing to stop the vote. The chief and his staff were eventually exonerated.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward.\n\nOnce Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that roiled Spain for months.\n\nPuigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police, stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe gripping turn of events, broadcast live on Spanish television channels, was likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nThe leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-center coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Puigdemont's return. Alberto N\u00fa\u00f1ez Feij\u00f3o posted on X that Puigdemont's reappearance was an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damaged Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan lawmakers before the vote, Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favor of independence and those against it.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nPuigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nBarry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8263318263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "10:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T10:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T10:18:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.spainenglish.com/2024/08/07/puigdemont-announces-return-journey-from-exile-for-catalan-investiture-debate/", "title": "Puigdemont announces 'return journey from exile' for Catalan investiture debate - Spain in English", "body": "Former Catalan president Carles Puigdemont has announced that he is taking his 'return journey from exile' in order to attend the investiture debate taking place in the Catalan Parliament on Thursday morning, despite facing likely arrest upon return to Spain.\n\nThe Catalan Socialist (PSC) candidate Salvador Illa is expected to become the new president of Catalonia on Thursday, which will mark a significant shift in the tide of Catalan politics - the first time a president in favour of Spanish unity will lead the regional government since 2010. ALSO READ: Pro-independence ERC party backs socialists to form government in Catalonia.\n\nIn a video posted on social media with English subtitles (see below), Puigdemont explained that 'in normal democratic conditions, for an MP like me to announce his intention to attend that session would be unnecessary'.\n\nPuigdemont is the figurehead of hardline pro-independence Junts per Catalunya (JxCat) party, and led Catalonia between 2016 and 2017 before fleeing Spain following a referendum on independence deemed illegal by the judiciary.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court has upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them. ALSO READ: Controversial Catalan amnesty law gets final approval in Spanish Congress.\n\nIt remains unclear how Puigdemont plans to return to the country and enter the regional parliament while evading police.\n\nThe Catalan police, the Mossos d'Esquadra, are putting together an increased security plan for around and inside Barcelona's Ciutadella park, where the Catalan Parliament is located, ahead of Thursday.\n\nThe Mossos will deploy additional officers ahead of the expected return of Puigdemont, with the aim of preventing him from entering the parliament building.\n\nOn Wednesday, dozens of security agents were already deployed around the park to control access and movements of potential demonstrators. Authorities plan to close the park and restrict access to any non-accredited person.\n\nThere will also be riot police deployed in the area in anticipation of two opposing demonstrations regarding the arrest of Puigdemont, one organised by the far-right Vox party and another by the former president's own party, JxCat.\n\nJordi Turull, secretary-general of JxCat, told Catalan broadcaster 324 on Tuesday that he would call for the leadership vote to be suspended if Puigdemont is detained, as 'it cannot take place in normal conditions' without him present.\n\nThe vote to invest Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the more moderate pro-independence party, Esquerra Republicana (ERC), after a bilateral deal last week, will kick off on Thursday at 10am local time.\n\nPuigdemont lived in Belgium from 2017 to 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament but has in recent months been based in southern France. Spanish media reports that he will be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a 'hybrid coup', adding 'if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do'.\n\nERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorised to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources.\n\nPuigdemont's party, JxCat, has announced on social media a 'welcoming' gathering for him at 9am on Thursday in the Passeig Llu\u00eds Companys in Barcelona. The Catalan investiture debate is scheduled to start at 10am in the parliament, just a short walk away.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the building's rooftop by helicopter after it was surrounded by nearly 1,000 anti-austerity activists protesting against budget cuts.", "source": {"uri": "spainenglish.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Spain in English"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-08-447991603", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:03:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:03:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:48:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/ex-catalan-leader-gives-police-the-slip-on-his-return-to-spain-after-nearly-7/article_f57d61a8-aabd-5047-b18b-9a38fb049146.html", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader gives police the slip on his return to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "Catalan police mans a checkpoint at a road in the outskirts of Barcelona, Spain, Thursday Aug. 8, 2024. The search for former Catalan president and pro-independence leader Carles Puigdemont by the Mossos d'Esquadra has clogged the main roads, resulting in traffic jams. The officers have activated operation 'cage' to locate the former president, who remains missing after returning to Barcelona following seven years of avoiding arrest for organising an independence referendum in 2017.\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated separatist who seven years after fleeing Spain sensationally returned to the country despite an outstanding arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on a day that Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president. The 61-year-old fugitive initially lived in Belgium after bolting Spain in 2017, but his latest place of residence wasn't known.\n\nPuigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward.\n\nOnce Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that roiled Spain for months.\n\nPuigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police, stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe turn of events was likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nThe leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-center coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Puigdemont's return. Alberto N\u00fa\u00f1ez Feij\u00f3o posted on X that Puigdemont's reappearance was an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damaged Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan lawmakers before the vote, Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favor of independence and those against it.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nPuigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nBarry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": Catalonia region is set to elect a new leader this week, although the event may be upstaged by the return of its former leader from self-imposed exile, despite a pending warrant for his arrest, APA reports citing Reuters.\n\nCarles Puigdemont is the figurehead of hardline separatist party Junts, and led Catalonia between 2016 and 2017 before fleeing Spain following a referendum on independence deemed illegal by the judiciary.\n\nIt remains unclear how he plans to return to the country and enter the regional parliament while evading police.\n\nJordi Turull, secretary-general of Junts, told broadcaster 324 on Tuesday that he would call for the leadership vote to be suspended if Puigdemont is detained, as \"it cannot take place in normal conditions\" without him present.\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, will kick off on Thursday at 10 a.m. local time (0800 GMT), according to the parliamentary speaker.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nA source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nPolitical scientist Toni Rodon of Barcelona's Pompeu Fabra University told Reuters that Puidgemont had possibly decided to come back because of the personal toll of living in exile.\n\n\"The amnesty has changed the game play, and the other strategy he can pursue can be more useful inside the Spanish borders even if he ends up in jail,\" Rodon added.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a \"hybrid coup\", adding \"if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do\".\n\nERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorised to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources.\n\nOfficers were also monitoring the sewer system in case it was used for alternative entry routes.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the building's rooftop by helicopter after it was surrounded by nearly 1,000 {"uri": "8265096384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:41:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:41:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:40:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/644716/World/Europe/Police-hunt-ex-Catalan-separatist-leader-after-shock-return-from-exile?ref=rss&format=simple&link=link", "title": "Police hunt ex-Catalan separatist leader after shock return from exile", "body": "MADRID -- Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont made a dramatic return to Spain on Thursday morning\n\nPolice in Barcelona are hunting for the separatist former leader of Catalonia, Carles Puigdemont, who made a dramatic return to Spain after a seven-year exile despite facing an outstanding arrest warrant.\n\nThe Mossos d'Esquadra - Catalan police - have set up roadblocks within Barcelona and leading out of the city as part of Operation Jaula - or \"cage\" - aimed at finding Mr Puigdemont, who was seen leaving a rally this morning in a car.\n\nFor much of the past several years he has lived in Brussels, after police indicted him on charges linked to a failed bid for Catalan independence in 2017.\n\nAt the time, Catalonia's pro-independence leaders including Puigdemont organized a referendum - which was ruled illegal by Spain's constitutional court - and later declared independence for the region. Madrid imposed direct rule on the region shortly after and Mr Puigdemont fled to Belgium.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Puigdemont briefly addressed hundreds of supporters who gathered near the Catalan parliament in Barcelona, shortly ahead of the expected investiture of a new head of the Catalan government.\n\nHe said he had returned \"to remind you that we are still here\" and added: \"Holding a referendum is not and will never be a crime.\"\n\nPuigdemont then disappeared.\n\nMany were expecting him to turn up inside the parliament building in time for the investiture ceremony at 10:00 (08:00 GMT), but he was nowhere to be seen.\n\nRoadblocks have now been set up across the city, a spokesperson for Catalonia's interior department said in a statement.\n\nSpanish TV also showed images from La Jonquera, a municipality bordering France, where police could be seen stopping cars and checking their boots.\n\nPuidgemont ally Aleix Sarri criticized the police operation on X, saying: \"Hundreds of policemen encircle Barcelona to arrest President Puigdemont. A hunt paid with public money to please the powers in Madrid. This is not what a democracy does.\"\n\nPolice reportedly used pepper spray to disperse Puigdemont supporters who gathered near the parliament.\n\nIgnacio Garriga of the far-right Vox party, which strongly opposes independence for Catalonia, said Vox would \"do everything necessary to ensure that Puigdemont is arrested\".\n\nSome Spanish commentators are puzzled at the fact that police were unable to arrest Mr Puigdemont despite him announcing he would return to Catalonia earlier this week.\n\nOn Wednesday, he posted a video on X saying that he had \"started the return trip from exile\" and added that his arrest would have been illegal and arbitrary.\n\nThere appear to be several motives behind Carles Puigdemont's return to Spain.\n\nFirstly, he wants to pressure the authorities into applying the country's new amnesty law - which withdraws legal action against Catalan nationalists - to him, after the supreme court excluded him from its application on technical grounds.\n\nHe also aims to disrupt the investiture of Socialist Salvador Illa as the new Catalan president today.\n\nThe former Spanish health minister would become the region's first non-nationalist leader since 2010.\n\nEqually important for Puigdemont is to assert himself and his Junts per Catalunya (JxCat) party as the main pro-independence force.\n\nHe is keen to cast his separatist rival, the Catalan Republican Left (ERC), as being complicit with Spanish unionism because of its agreement to support Mr Illa's investiture.\n\nUntil a new local government is in place, ERC is still responsible for the Catalan police force, making the former regional president's return particularly uncomfortable for the party. -- BBC", "source": {"uri": "saudigazette.com.sa", "dataType": "news", "title": "Saudi "https://saudigazette.com.sa/uploads/images/2024/08/08/2412943.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9791466", "eventUri": "eng-9791466", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-08-448089931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:27:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:27:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/ex-catalan-leader-puigdemont-a-fugitive-since-2017-returns-to-spain-but-then-he-vanishes/article_d914f908-a12e-53de-b435-a1d1bb2e8642.html", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader Puigdemont, a fugitive since 2017, returns to Spain. But then he vanishes again", "body": "Not a subscriber? Buy a Day Pass or just this story using our new Digital Wallet\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader and fugitive Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated campaigner for Catalan independence who made a sensational return to Spain and an equally sensational getaway from a speech in the city with the alleged help of a local police officer.\n\nThe events took place nearly seven years after Puigdemont fled Spain after a failed independence bid, with an outstanding arrest warrant pending against him.\n\nPuigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on a day that Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president. The 61-year-old initially lived in Belgium after bolting from Spain in 2017, but his latest place of residence wasn't known.\n\nPuigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nCatalan police arrested one of their own officers on charges of aiding Puigdemont's getaway, the force's press office told The Associated Press. No further details were available.\n\nAbout three hours after Puigdemont vanished, Catalan police called off the manhunt without saying why.\n\nThe Catalan police force is called Mossos d'Esquadra and operates separately from Spain's Policia Nacional. At the time of the 2017 ballot, the Spanish government suspended the Mossos' chief and placed the force under investigation for failing to stop the vote. The chief and his staff were eventually exonerated.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward.\n\nOnce Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that roiled Spain for months.\n\nPuigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police, stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe gripping turn of events, broadcast live on Spanish television channels, was likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nThe leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-center coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Puigdemont's return. Alberto N\u00fa\u00f1ez Feij\u00f3o posted on X that Puigdemont's reappearance was an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damaged Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan lawmakers before the vote, Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favor of independence and those against it.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nPuigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nBarry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Mossos d'Esquadra"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Parliament"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448050912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:54:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:54:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:51:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2024/08/08/ex-catalan-leader-gives-police-the-slip-on-return-spain-after-nearly-7-years-as-fugitive/74716773007/", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader gives police the slip on his return to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "Barcelona, Spain -- Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated separatist who seven years after fleeing Spain sensationally returned to the country despite an outstanding arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on a day that Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president. The 61-year-old fugitive initially lived in Belgium after bolting from Spain in 2017, but his latest place of residence wasn't known.\n\nPuigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nCatalan police arrested one of their own officers on charges of aiding Puigdemont's getaway, the force's press office told The Associated Press. No further details were available.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward.\n\nOnce Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that roiled Spain for months.\n\nPuigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police, stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe gripping turn of events, broadcast live on Spanish television channels, was likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nThe leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-center coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Puigdemont's return. Alberto N\u00fa\u00f1ez Feij\u00f3o posted on X that Puigdemont's reappearance was an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damaged Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan lawmakers before the vote, Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favor of independence and those against it.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nPuigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.", "source": {"uri": "detroitnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Detroit News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carles_Puigdemont", "type": {"uri": "8263774061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "15:07:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T15:07:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T15:07:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-says-he-is-returning-to-spain-faces-likely-arrest-/7733334.html", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont says he is returning to Spain, faces likely arrest", "body": "Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont said on Wednesday he was returning after seven years in self-imposed exile to Spain, where he would likely be arrested over his role in the region's 2017 independence bid.\n\nHis arrest and potential imprisonment before he might face trial could unleash fresh turmoil in Catalonia and threaten the fragile Socialist-led coalition ruling Spain, which relies on Puigdemont's hardline Junts party to pass legislation.\n\nTo secure Junts' legislative support for Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's government, Spain's parliament in May approved an amnesty law designed to allow Puigdemont a safe return from Belgium.\n\nThe amnesty aimed to cancel legal proceedings against hundreds of separatists involved in Catalonia's 2017 illegal referendum, but Spain's Supreme Court ruled last month that the law did not apply to an embezzlement charge against Puigdemont and upheld an arrest warrant he faces.\n\nStill, Puigdemont said he remained committed to attending the Catalan parliament's session that is due to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont finished second.\n\nThe swearing-in is scheduled for Thursday. Puigdemont said he would keep his word and be in Barcelona then.\n\n\"I have started the return trip from exile,\" he said in a video posted on X. He also said in the video message that his arrest would be illegal and arbitrary.\n\nNeither Puigdemont nor Junts on Wednesday said whether he had already entered Spain.\n\nThursday's session is poised to appoint Socialist Salvador Illa as the new Catalan president, ending over a decade of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont's supporters plan to welcome him on Thursday morning on a Barcelona boulevard near the regional parliament, setting the stage for a potentially dramatic arrest witnessed by reporters and bystanders.\n\nModerate separatist party Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya, currently governing Catalonia, called Puigdemont's return an \"exceptional moment\" and said it would attend the welcoming event.\n\nThat might require a delicate balancing act from the party, which as leader of the regional government is responsible for the regional police force that could arrest Puigdemont. Esquerra will also lend its key votes for Illa to be elected president in exchange for a deal under which Catalonia would gain autonomy in collecting and managing taxes.\n\nBoth Esquerra and Junts have backed the Socialist-led national government in Madrid.\n\nIf the judge in charge of his case issues a pre-trial imprisonment, Puigdemont is expected to appeal for his release to Spain's {"uri": "8264799646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:38:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:38:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:33:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13722465/Carles-Puigdemont-ex-Catalan-leader-returns-Spain-nearly-7-years-fugitive.html", "title": "Carles Puigdemont, ex-Catalan leader, returns to Spain after nearly...", "body": "BARCELONA, Spain (AP) - Former Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, who fled Spain after organizing an illegal independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago, returned to the country on Thursday despite a pending arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont defiantly appeared in Barcelona after traveling from Belgium and faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain - a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain\u00b4s central government.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nThe event was organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia\u00b4s parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nCatalan independence leader and former President Carles Puigdemont addresses supporters after his arrival near the Catalan parliament to attend the investiture debate in Barcelona, Spain, Thursday Aug. 8, 2024. Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who left Spain after organizing an independence referendum in the Spanish northeastern region seven years ago, announced that he plans to return home on Thursday despite the likelihood of being arrested on his return. (AP Photo/Joan Mateu)\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont\u00b4s presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn\u00b4t immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrest.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain\u00b4s Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain\u00b4s parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Puigdemont could initially be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nThe former Catalan leader\u00b4s return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa\u00b4s Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia\u00b4s parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday.\n\nBarry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.\n\nSupporters of Catalan independence leader and former President Carles Puigdemont, wait for his arrival near the Catalan parliament to attend the investiture debate in Barcelona, Spain, Thursday Aug. 8, 2024. {"uri": "8264812750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:43:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:43:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:43:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3273704/catalan-separatist-carles-puigdemont-returns-spain-after-7-years-despite-threat-arrest", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont returns to Spain after 7 years despite threat of arrest", "body": "Carles Puigdemont\u2019s presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the issue of Catalan independence\n\nFormer Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, who fled Spain after organising an illegal independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago, returned to the country on Thursday despite a pending arrest warrant.\n\nPuigdemont defiantly appeared in Barcelona after travelling from Belgium and faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain.\n\nPuigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain \u2013 a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain\u2019s central government.\n\nPuigdemont appeared in a central Barcelona park where several thousand separatist supporters who had gathered in expectation of his arrival waved Catalan flags. He punched the air to cheers on a bright, sunny day.\n\nThe event was organised by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts), hours before a new regional government was to take office nearby.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia\u2019s parliament building is located behind walls. Puigdemont walked toward the building followed by masses of supporters.\n\nPuigdemont had earlier announced publicly he was going back to Spain, though he gave no travel details.\n\nPuigdemont\u2019s presence in Spain is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smouldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t immediately clear how authorities would proceed if Puigdemont was arrest.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain\u2019s Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain\u2019s parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Puigdemont could initially be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nThe former Catalan leader\u2019s return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa\u2019s Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia\u2019s parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, The parliamentary speaker has yet to confirm the date.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nA source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a \"hybrid coup\", adding \"if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do\".\n\nERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorized to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources.\n\nOfficers were also monitoring the sewer system in case it was used for alternative entry routes.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the
