{"uri": "8265362350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:24:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/08/08/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-evades-capture-on-chaotic-return-to-spain/", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont evades capture on chaotic return to Spain", "body": "Former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont defied an arrest warrant to appear at a rally in Spain's Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile and then vanished, sparking a frantic search by police to apprehend him.\n\nAmid a heavy police presence, Puigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital from a platform near the Catalan parliament, telling them he aimed to revive the independence drive that plunged Spain into political crisis in 2017.\n\n\"They thought they'd be celebrating my arrest and they thought that this punishment would dissuade us, and you,\" he said. \"Well, they are wrong.\"\n\nWhen he had finished speaking Puigdemont went backstage, after which police and media were unable to locate him.\n\nA loudspeaker announcement called on the crowd to accompany Puigdemont in a march towards the Catalan parliament. But while senior officials of Puigdemont's Junts party and members of the moderate separatist Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya made their way to the building, he instead got into a white car which belonged to a regional police officer, a Catalan government source said.\n\nA spokesperson for the regional police, known as the Mossos d'Esquadra, said one of its officers had been arrested \"as part of the investigation into Puigdemont's whereabouts.\"\n\nTRAFFIC CHAOS\n\nThe hunt for the separatist leader created traffic chaos in Barcelona and near the border with France as police set up roadblocks and searched car boots.\n\nThe search for Puigdemont was later called off, a Mossos spokeseperson said, without explaining why.\n\nSeveral Puigdemont supporters clashed with police in a bid to breach the cordon surrounding the park housing the parliament building. Officers clad in riot gear used batons and pepper spray to deter them.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since.\n\nHe faces an arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement related to the 2017 independence referendum ruled illegal by the Spanish courts, but he insists the vote was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nA debate to swear in Socialist Salvador Illa as Catalonia\u00b4s new president, ending a decade of separatist rule, began amid confusion and speculation about Puigdemont's whereabouts.\n\nA Catalan government spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" he said.\n\nReacting to news that Puigdemont had again absconded from under the noses of a large deployment of the Catalan regional police force, a Supreme Court source said the judge had been clear in his instructions that the former regional president was to be arrested.\n\n\"The Mossos know that they have a detention order. The judge's writ reminded the state security forces that the national arrest warrant for aggravated embezzlement remained active and they had the obligation to detain him and bring him before the courts.\"\n\nTwo national police unions criticised the failure to arrest Puigdemont.\n\n\"Where are the Mossos? The best-paid police force in Spain incapable of doing their job, of arresting the coup-monger and fugitive from justice Puigdemont,\" police union Jusapol said on X.\n\nTwo sources with links to the Catalan government said it was realising it had a problem with some rogue Mossos, who appear to be loyal to Puigdemont.\n\n\"UNBEARABLE HUMILIATION\"\n\nAlberto Nunez Feijoo, leader of the opposition People\u00b4s Party (PP) blamed Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez for the situation, describing it as \"an unbearable humiliation.\"\n\n\"It\u00b4s unforgivable to damage Spain's image like this,\" Feijoo said on X.\n\nA government spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment, nor did Puigdemont\u00b4s lawyer.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont had announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\nHis arrest could jeopardise the Socialist-led national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe crowd of thousands, who had gathered near the parliament to welcome him, hoped his return would help build momentum towards independence, which has lost support in recent years.\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nNo-one had expected him to disappear again.\n\nFormer Barcelona Mayor Xavier Trias, who was present at the gathering, described Puigdemont as a magician.\n\n\"It was magic,\" he told Reuters of Puigdemont\u00b4s escape.", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8263956883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "17:23:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T17:23:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T17:21:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/08/07/fugitive-ex-catalan-leader-plans-return-to-spain-despite-threat-of-arrest/", "title": "Fugitive ex-Catalan leader plans return to Spain despite threat of arrest", "body": "The political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many Puigdemont supporters.\n\nCarles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain after organising an illegal independence referendum, has announced that he plans to return home on Thursday despite the likelihood of his arrest.\n\nMr Puigdemont, 61, who fled to Belgium after the breakaway bid in October 2017 quickly collapsed, said that he would attend an event organised by his political party, Together for Catalonia, near Barcelona's regional parliament building hours before a new regional government takes office.\n\nHe did not say when or how he would arrive in Spain.\n\nThe political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many Puigdemont supporters.\n\nThe Mossos D'Esquadra, the regional police in Catalonia, say that they intend to obey court orders to arrest Mr Puigdemont, if he does return.\n\nIn his announcement made on YouTube, Mr Puigdemont recognised that he \"cannot attend freely\" the scheduled parliamentary session and accused authorities of \"a long persecution\" over the unsuccessful breakaway attempt.\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he said.\n\nMr Puigdemont's return is likely to generate renewed political tension over the issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis in Spain.\n\nMr Puigdemont and his supporters have long taken a confrontational and at times provocative stance toward Spain's central authorities, especially the Madrid-based government.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana.\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Mr Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate on Thursday, scheduled shortly after Mr Puigdemont's first planned event and which will take place amid tight security.\n\nMr Puigdemont, who is wanted on charges of embezzlement during the secession attempt, has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in north-east Spain -- a decades-long struggle.\n\nHis largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Mr Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Mr Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nMr Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nMr Puigdemont's escape from Spain became the stuff of legend among his followers, and a huge source of embarrassment for Spanish law enforcement.\n\nHe is a celebrated figurehead for many Catalans who want to break away from the rest of Spain.\n\nEarlier this year, Mr Puigdemont denied that he had hidden in a car trunk to avoid detection while slipping across the border after the referendum.\n\nThe subsequent legal crackdown landed several of his cohorts in prison until Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez's government pardoned them.", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-448075638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:16:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:16:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:01:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/police-hunt-ex-catalan-separatist-085900274.html", "title": "Police hunt ex-Catalan separatist leader after shock return from exile", "body": "Police in Barcelona are hunting for the separatist former leader of Catalonia, Carles Puigdemont, who made a dramatic return to Spain after a seven-year exile despite facing an outstanding arrest warrant.\n\nThe Mossos d'Esquadra - Catalan police - set up roadblocks within Barcelona and leading out of the city as part of Operation Jaula - or \"cage\" - aimed at finding Mr Puigdemont, who was seen leaving a rally this morning in a car. The operation was reportedly ended a few hours later.\n\nFor much of the past several years he has lived in Brussels, after police indicted him on charges linked to a failed bid for Catalan independence in 2017.\n\nAt the time, Catalonia's pro-independence leaders including Mr Puigdemont organised a referendum - which was ruled illegal by Spain's constitutional court - and later declared independence for the region. Madrid imposed direct rule on the region shortly after and Mr Puigdemont fled to Belgium.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Mr Puigdemont briefly addressed hundreds of supporters who gathered near the Catalan parliament in Barcelona, shortly ahead of the expected investiture of a new head of the Catalan government.\n\nHe said he had returned \"to remind you that we are still here\" and added: \"Holding a referendum is not and will never be a crime.\"\n\nMr Puigdemont then disappeared.\n\nMany were expecting him to turn up inside the parliament building in time for the investiture ceremony at 10:00 (08:00 GMT), but he was nowhere to be seen.\n\nA Catalan police officer was detained on suspicion of helping Mr Puigdemont flee, a spokesperson for the Mossos d'Esquadra said.\n\nThe officer allegedly owns a car in which Mr Puigdemont escaped after making his address, Spanish media said.\n\nRoadblocks have now been set up across the city, a spokesperson for Catalonia's interior department said in a statement.\n\nSpanish TV also showed images from La Jonquera, a municipality bordering France, where police could be seen stopping cars and checking the boots.\n\nPuigdemont ally Aleix Sarri criticised the police operation on X, saying: \"Hundreds of policemen encircle Barcelona to arrest President Puigdemont. A hunt paid with public money to please the powers in Madrid. This is not what a democracy does.\"\n\nPolice reportedly used pepper spray to disperse Puigdemont supporters who gathered near the parliament.\n\nIgnacio Garriga of the far-right Vox party, which strongly opposes independence for Catalonia, said Vox would \"do everything necessary to ensure that Puigdemont is arrested\".\n\nSome Spanish commentators are puzzled at the fact that police were unable to arrest Mr Puigdemont despite him announcing he would return to Catalonia earlier this week.\n\nOn Wednesday, he posted a video on X saying that he had \"started the return trip from exile\" and added that his arrest would have been illegal and arbitrary.\n\nThere appear to be several motives behind Carles Puigdemont's return to Spain.\n\nFirstly, he wants to pressure the authorities into applying the country's new amnesty law - which withdraws legal action against Catalan nationalists - to him, after the supreme court excluded him from its application on technical grounds.\n\nHe also aims to disrupt the investiture of Socialist Salvador Illa as the new Catalan president today.\n\nThe former Spanish health minister would become the region's first non-nationalist leader since 2010.\n\nEqually important for Mr Puigdemont is to assert himself and his Junts per Catalunya (JxCat) party as the main pro-independence force.\n\nHe is keen to cast his separatist rival, the Catalan Republican Left (ERC), as being complicit with Spanish unionism because of its agreement to support Mr Illa's investiture.\n\nUntil a new local government is in place, ERC is still responsible for the Catalan police force, making the former regional president's return particularly uncomfortable for the party.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": The political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many of Puigdemont's supporters.\n\nThe Mossos D'Esquadra, the regional police in Catalonia, say that they intend to obey court orders to arrest Puigdemont, if he does return.\n\nIn his announcement on YouTube, Puigdemont recognized that he \"cannot attend freely\" the scheduled parliamentary session and accused authorities of \"a long persecution\" over the unsuccessful breakaway attempt.\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he said.\n\nFILE - Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont speaks at a press conference in Alghero, Italy, Oct. 4, 2021. (AP Photo/Gloria Calvi, File)\n\nPuigdemont's return is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis in Spain.\n\nPuigdemont and his supporters have long taken a confrontational and at times provocative stance toward Spain's central authorities, especially the Madrid-based government.\n\nThe former Catalan leader\u00b4s return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia\u00b4s parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday, scheduled shortly after Puigdemont's first planned event and which will take place amid tight security.\n\nPuigdemont, who is wanted on charges of misuse of public funds, among other offenses, during the secession attempt, has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain - a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain\u00b4s Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain\u00b4s parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nPuigdemont\u00b4s escape from Spain became the stuff of legend among his followers, and a huge source of embarrassment for Spanish law enforcement. He is a celebrated figurehead for many Catalans who want to break away from the rest of Spain.\n\nEarlier this year, Puigdemont denied that he had hidden in a car trunk to avoid detection while slipping across the border after the referendum. The subsequent legal crackdown landed several of his cohorts in prison until Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez\u00b4s government pardoned them.\n\nBarry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.", AFP\n\nThe parliament of Spain's Catalonia region is expected to elect a new leader this week, although the event may be upstaged by the return of its former leader from self-imposed exile, despite a pending warrant for his arrest.\n\nCarles Puigdemont is the figurehead of hardline separatist party Junts, and led Catalonia between 2016 and 2017 before fleeing Spain following a referendum on independence deemed illegal by the judiciary.\n\nIt remains unclear how he plans to return to the country and enter the regional parliament while evading police.\n\nJordi Turull, secretary-general of Junts, told broadcaster 324 on Tuesday that he would call for the leadership vote to be suspended if Puigdemont is detained, as \"it cannot take place in normal conditions\" without him present.\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, is expected to be held on Thursday. {"uri": "2024-08-448120019", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:55:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:55:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:15:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/fugitive-catalan-ex-leader-puigdemont-returns-spain-vanishes-again-1850415", "title": "Fugitive Catalan Ex-leader Puigdemont Returns To Spain And Vanishes Again", "body": "Carles Puigdemont -- the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain over his role in a failed 2017 independence bid for the wealthy region -- returned to Spain on Thursday to address supporters before vanishing despite an extensive police deployment to arrest him.\n\nPolice have set up roadblocks in Barcelona and other parts of Catalonia to try to find Puigdemont, who remains the target of an arrest warrant.\n\nEarlier on Thursday, Puigdemont delivered a short speech to thousands gathered near the Catalan regional parliament, which is set to elect a new leader later in the day.\n\n\"Long live a free Catalonia!\" he shouted when he climbed onto the stage in Barcelona, under the watch of dozens of police officers who made no attempt to detain him.\n\n\"I have come here to remind you that we are still here,\" he said as many in the crowd waved red, yellow and blue Catalan independence flags.\n\nHe then disappeared.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, had been expected to try to enter the parliament building for the investiture vote, which went ahead without him.\n\nCatalonia's regional police force said it had arrested one of its officers on suspicion of helping fugitive Puigdemont flee.\n\nThe officer allegedly owns a car in which Puigdemont left the scene, according to Spanish media reports.\n\nAround 3,500 people had turned out to hear Puigdemont speak, according to Barcelona city hall.\n\n\"He is a very noble person,\" said Nuria Pujol, a woman in her fifties who come from the Alt Penedes region for the event.\n\n\"(He's) the only one who believes in independence and has not stopped believing,\" she told AFP.\n\nPuigdemont's dramatic return came just days after Spain's governing Socialists struck a deal with moderate Catalan separatist party ERC to make the Socialist candidate, Salvador Illa, the next head of the Catalan regional government.\n\nERC is a political rival of Puigdemont's more hardline separatist JxCAT party.\n\nThe Socialists won the most seats in the Catalan regional election in May but failed to get a majority and the support of the ERC is crucial.\n\nIf a new Catalan regional government is not formed by August 26, a fresh election will be held in October.\n\nPuigdemont led the regional government of Catalonia in 2017, when it pushed ahead with an independence referendum despite a court ban, followed by a short-lived declaration of independence.\n\nHe fled Spain shortly after the independence bid to avoid prosecution and has since lived in Belgium and more recently France.\n\nWhile Spain's parliament in May passed an amnesty law for those involved in the botched secession bid, the Supreme Court ruled on July 1 that the measure would not fully apply to Puigdemont.\n\n\"A country that has an amnesty law and does not apply it, has a problem with democracy,\" he said in his speech.\n\nThe head of Spain's main opposition Popular Party, Alberto Nunez Feijoo, called Puigdemont's return and then disappearance \"an unbearable humiliation\".\n\n\"It is unforgivable to damage Spain's image like this,\" he added.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez agreed to the amnesty law in exchange for JxCAT's crucial support in the national parliament for his fragile minority government.\n\nThe move sparked huge street protests that were organised by the right wing.\n\nSanchez is now facing opposition from parts of his own Socialist party as well as the right over a proposal to give Catalonia full control of the taxes collected in the region.\n\nThe measure was promised to the ERC in exchange for the party's support for Illa in Thursday's Catalan investiture vote.\n\nThe proposal has for decades been one of the main demands of Catalan independence parties but critics argue it would deprive the central state of a substantial source of revenue.\n\nIt must still be approved by Spain's national parliament.\n\nIf Illa passes Thursday's investiture vote, he will be the first head of Catalonia's regional government since 2010 who does not come from the separatist camp.\n\nThe former health minister has defended the tax agreement made with the ERC, saying it was \"favourable for all Catalans\".\n\nBut former Socialist deputy prime minister Alfonso Guerra has said the tax agreement opens \"a path towards a federal system and the independence of Catalonia\".", and vanishes again", "body": "Carles Puigdemont -- the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain over his role in a failed 2017 independence bid for the wealthy region -- returned to Spain on Thursday to address supporters before vanishing despite an extensive police deployment to arrest him.\n\nPolice have set up roadblocks in Barcelona and other parts of Catalonia to try to find Puigdemont, who remains the target of an arrest warrant.\n\nEarlier on Thursday, Puigdemont delivered a short speech to thousands gathered near the Catalan regional parliament, which is set to elect a new leader later in the day.\n\n\"Long live a free Catalonia!\" he shouted when he climbed onto the stage in Barcelona, under the watch of dozens of police officers who made no attempt to detain him.\n\n\"I have come here to remind you that we are still here,\" he said as many in the crowd waved red, yellow and blue Catalan independence flags.\n\nHe then disappeared.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, had been expected to try to enter the parliament building for the investiture vote, which went ahead without him.\n\nCatalonia's regional police force said it had arrested one of its officers on suspicion of helping returns to Spain and vanishes again", "body": "Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain over his role in a failed 2017 independence bid for the wealthy region, returned to Spain on Thursday after seven years on the run despite a pending arrest warrant but promptly disappeared again.\n\nPuigdemont shouted \"Long live a free Catalonia!\" as he climbed onto a stage in Barcelona to address thousands gathered near the Catalan regional parliament, which is set to elect a new leader later in the day.\n\n\"I have come here to remind you that we are still here,\" he said as many in the crowd waved red, yellow and blue Catalan independence flags.\n\nAfter his brief address, Puigdemont appeared to head towards the nearby Catalan parliament but the assembly began an investiture vote to pick a new leader for the region without him being present.\n\nIt was not immediately clear where he was.\n\nPolice had set up road blocks in Barcelona and were searching cars to try to find Puigdemont, according to Spanish media reports.\n\nContacted by AFP, police declined to comment if such an operation was underway.\n\nNuria Pujol, a woman in her fifties who came to prosecution and has since lived in Belgium and more recently France.\n\nWhile Spain's parliament in May passed an amnesty law for those involved in the botched secession bid, the Supreme Court ruled {"uri": "8265531111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "15:18:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T15:18:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:17:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/who-is-carles-puigdemont-why-is-his-return-to-barcelona-causing-such-a-tumult-13802569.html", "title": "Who is Carles Puigdemont? Why is his return to Barcelona causing such a tumult?", "body": "Carles Puigdemont on Thursday made a sensational return to Spain and an equally sensational getaway from a speech in the city with the alleged help of a local police officer.\n\nPuigdemont, the Catalonia leader and leader of the hardline Junts party, returned to Barcelona on Thursday after spending seven years in exile.\n\nThe 61-year-old fled Spain after a failed bid for Catalonia's independence.\n\nA manhunt for Puigdemont, who has an outstanding arrest warrant against him, is underway.\n\nBut who is Puigdemont? Why is his return so controversial?\n\nPuigdemont was born on December 29, 1962 in the tiny village of Amer.\n\nAs per France 24, the village, with its population of just 2,200, is not far from Girona - which itself is around 100 kilometres northeast of Barcelona.\n\nPuigdemont, nicknamed Pugi by his friends, descended from a long line of bakers. Puigdemont, like his forbearers, was an ardent nationalist.\n\nPuigdemont studied for a degree in Catalan philology at the University College of Girona.\n\nHowever, in 1983, he decided to become a journalist after he had a serious car accident. He began his journalistic career as a copy editor at El Punt Avui.\n\nHe became editor next - and ascended to editor-in-chief.\n\nHis colleagues recall his separatist leanings.\n\n\"When we played pinball and he lost the ball, he'd call the machine a 'Spanish whore',\" one of his former colleagues said.\n\nPolitics\n\nPuigdemont in 1991 began lobbying to change the Gerona's name to its Catalan counterpart Girona.\n\nHe also founded the youth group JNC.\n\nThe outfit had links to the nationalist party of the Democratic Convergence of Catalonia.\n\nIt would later be reestablished as Catalan European Democratic Party (PDECAT) in 2016, according to France24.\n\nPuigdemont's political career began in earnest in 2007 when he stood for Girona mayor.\n\nIn 2011, Puigdemont was elected Mayor of Girona.\n\nThis made him the first non-socialist mayor in the history of Spanish democracy.\n\nOn January 12, 2016, Puigdemont was officially sworn in as the 130th President of the Government of Catalonia.\n\nHe made history by becoming the first president of Catalonia not to swear fealty to Spain's Constitution and King Felipe VI.\n\nPuigdemont dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nSecession and exile\n\nIn 2017, Puigdemont, as regional president and separatist party leader, tried to get Catalonia to secede from Spain.\n\nAs per Al Jazeera, millions of Catalans took the polls with a huge majority of voters backing independence.\n\nMeanwhile, violence unfolded as the central government attempted to halt the vote.\n\nFour weeks later, the region declared independence.\n\nSpain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nMadrid then activated Article 155 - letting the national government take full control of the region.\n\nSpain also dismissed Puigdemont and his cabinet and called fresh elections.\n\nPuigdemont and his minister then left for Belgium\n\nAs per Al Jazeera, Puigdemont said he went to \"the capital of Europe\" so that he could speak from a position of \"freedom and safety.\"\n\nHe said he would not return unless he was guaranteed a free and fair trial.\n\nIn December 2017, Puigdemont contested Catalan's regional elections and was re-elected to Parliament.\n\nThe secessionists also kept a narrow majority in the Catalan Parliament.\n\nThough Puigdemont called for new unconditional talks with the Spanish government and even proposed meeting the prime minister, his proposal was rejected.\n\nThough the 61-year-old initially lived in Belgium, his latest place of residence remained known.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempted secession.\n\nIn 2018, Puigdemont was stopped by German police while travelling from Finland to Brussels by car.\n\nThis, after the Spanish Supreme Court issued an arrest warrant against him.\n\nPuigdemont on Thursday made a sensational return to Spain and an equally sensational getaway from a speech in the city with the alleged help of a local police officer.\n\nPuigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nCatalan police arrested one of their own officers on charges of aiding Puigdemont's getaway, the force's press office told The Associated Press.\n\nNo further details were available.\n\nAbout three hours after Puigdemont vanished, Catalan police called off the manhunt without saying why.\n\nThe Catalan police force is called Mossos d'Esquadra and operates separately from Spain's Policia Nacional. At the time of the 2017 ballot, the Spanish government suspended the Mossos' chief and placed the force under investigation for failing to stop the vote. The chief and his staff were eventually exonerated.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward.\n\nOnce Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France.\n\nWhy is his return controversial?\n\nBecause Puigdemont's return comes on the very day when a new socialist government was being sworn in at Catalonia's Parliament.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nAs per Al Jazeera, though the socialists won the recent polls they failed to nab a majority.\n\nThe support of the ERC proved crucial to forming the regional government.\n\nThe new government had to be sworn by August 26 or fresh elections would be held in October.\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday.\n\nPuigdemont could also hurt Spain's Socialist-led coalition government at the Centre.\n\nThe Central's government has a shaky alliance with Puigdemont's Junts - on whom it depends to pass legislation, as per Al Jazeera.\n\nComplicating matters is the fact that a contentious amnesty bill, crafted by the Centre, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot.\n\nHowever, the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court which has argued that the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nPuigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested.\n\nWhat do experts say?\n\nAccording to BBC, Puigdemont by returning wants to pressure authorities into including him under the ambit of the amnesty bill.\n\n\"The amnesty law has created the conditions for him to return,\" Pablo Sim\u00f3n, a political scientist at Carlos III University in Madrid told The New York Times. \"Returning is the only thing he can do in order to continue to play the victim.\"\n\nPuigdemont also wants to make sure his Junts party is viewed by the public as the main party fighting for Catalonia's independence.\n\nAt the same time, he wants to make sure the rival ERC is seen as hand-in-glove with those fighting for Catalonia to remain in Spain.\n\nBut others think it's too late.\n\n\"It's Puigdemont's last dance,\" Ignacio Lago, a professor of political science at Pompeu Fabra University in Barcelona, told The New York Times.\n\nLola Garc\u00eda, the deputy editor of the Catalan daily La Vanguardia, a paper which has been close to the Junts, told The Guardian, \"The possibility of Puigdemont being jailed might complicate things for the Spanish government, although a change of government wouldn't be in his interest at this juncture.\"\n\nBut it won't resuscitate the unity of the independence movement nor the independence process.\"\n\n\"Things are complicated in the sense that there's this interest in stopping him. But at the end of the day, he's a member of parliament. He's a former president. So if he is arrested, this would be against the immunity of the members of parliament,\" Mar Aquilera Varques, a constitutional law professor at Barcelona University, told Al Jazeera.\n\n\"There are some people who are tired of this political crisis. But many people in Catalonia still want independence,\" she added.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The parliamentary speaker has yet to confirm the date.\n\nEXCLUDED FROM AMNESTY\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nA source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a \"hybrid coup\", adding \"if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do\".\n\nERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorised to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources.\n\nOfficers were also monitoring the sewer system in case it was used for alternative entry routes.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the building's rooftop by helicopter after it was surrounded by nearly 1,000 anti-austerity activists protesting against budget cuts.\n\n(Reporting by David Latona and Bel\u00e9n Carre\u00f1o; {"uri": "8265375440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:34:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:34:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://newseu.cgtn.com/news/2024-08-08/Catalan-leader-Puigdemont-escapes-arrest-amid-chaotic-return-to-Spain-1vU3TJM3UfS/p.html", "title": "Catalan leader Puigdemont escapes arrest on 'return trip from exile'", "body": "Former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont defied an arrest warrant to appear at a rally in Spain's Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile and then vanished, sparking a frantic search by police to apprehend him.\n\nAmid a heavy police presence, Puigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital from a platform near the Catalan parliament, telling them he aimed to revive the independence drive that plunged Spain into a political crisis in 2017.\n\n\"They thought they'd be celebrating my arrest and they thought that this punishment would dissuade us, and you,\" he said. \"Well, they are wrong.\"\n\nWhen he had finished speaking Puigdemont went backstage, after which police and media were unable to locate him.\n\nThe hunt for his whereabouts created traffic chaos in Barcelona and near the border with France as police set up roadblocks and searched car boots.\n\nCatalonia's regional police force said on Thursday it had arrested one of its officers on suspicion of helping Puigdemont flee. The officer allegedly owns a car in which Puigdemont escaped after briefly addressing a few thousand supporters near the Catalan parliament, Spanish media said.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He faces an arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nHis supporters hope his return will rekindle enthusiasm for the Catalan independence cause, which lost support in recent years.\n\nSenior officials of Puigdemont's Junts party, including parliament speaker Josep Rull, and members of the moderate separatist Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya which currently runs the regional government led a march to the Catalan parliament after the rally.\n\nA debate to swear in Socialist Salvador Illa as Catalonia's new president, ending a decade of separatist rule, began amid confusion and speculation about Puigdemont's whereabouts.\n\nA Catalan Interior Ministry spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" he said.\n\nA Supreme Court spokesperson declined to comment on Puigdemont's disappearance in Barcelona. A government spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment, nor did Puigdemont's lawyer.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont had announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\nHis arrest could jeopardize the national government's fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nIn the morning, a crowd of thousands had gathered near the parliament to welcome him and hear him speak.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, began an hour later.\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe embezzlement charges were related to the 2017 independence referendum ruled illegal by the Spanish courts.\n\nPuigdemont insists the vote was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender,' 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, risking his life to move the country forward,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "newseu.cgtn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "newseu.cgtn.com"}, {"uri": "8263958376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "17:23:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T17:23:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T17:22:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/fugitive-ex-catalan-leader-plans-return-to-spain-despite-threat-of-arrest-1659005.html", "title": "Fugitive ex-Catalan leader plans return to Spain despite threat of arrest | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain after organising an illegal independence referendum, has announced that he plans to return home on Thursday despite the likelihood of his arrest.\n\nMr Puigdemont, 61, who fled to Belgium after the breakaway bid in October 2017 quickly collapsed, said that he would attend an event organised by his political party, Together for Catalonia, near Barcelona's regional parliament building hours before a new regional government takes office.\n\nHe did not say when or how he would arrive in Spain.\n\nThe political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many Puigdemont supporters.\n\nThe Mossos D'Esquadra, the regional police in Catalonia, say that they intend to obey court orders to arrest Mr Puigdemont, if he does return.\n\nIn his announcement made on YouTube, Mr Puigdemont recognised that he \"cannot attend freely\" the scheduled parliamentary session and accused authorities of \"a long persecution\" over the unsuccessful breakaway attempt.\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he said.\n\nMr Puigdemont's return is likely to generate renewed political tension over the issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis in Spain.\n\nMr Puigdemont and his supporters have long taken a confrontational and at times provocative stance toward Spain's central authorities, especially the Madrid-based government.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana.\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Mr Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate on Thursday, scheduled shortly after Mr Puigdemont's first planned event and which will take place amid tight security.\n\nMr Puigdemont, who is wanted on charges of embezzlement during the secession attempt, has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in north-east Spain -- a decades-long struggle.\n\nHis largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Mr Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Mr Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nMr Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nMr Puigdemont's escape from Spain became the stuff of legend among his followers, and a huge source of embarrassment for Spanish law enforcement.\n\nHe is a celebrated figurehead for many Catalans who want to break away from the rest of Spain.\n\nEarlier this year, Mr Puigdemont denied that he had hidden in a car trunk to avoid detection while slipping across the border after the referendum.\n\nThe subsequent legal crackdown landed several of his cohorts in prison until Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez's government pardoned them.", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-445738942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:07:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:07:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:04:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3043845-update-1-spains-catalonia-to-elect-new-leader-as-ex-leader-puigdemonts-arrest-looms", "title": "UPDATE 1-Spain's Catalonia to elect new leader as ex-leader Puigdemont's arrest looms", "body": "A source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid. Political scientist Toni Rodon of Barcelona's Pompeu Fabra University told Reuters that Puidgemont had possibly decided to come back because of the personal toll of living in exile.\n\nThe parliament of Spain's Catalonia region is set to elect a new leader this week, although the event may be upstaged by the return of its former leader from self-imposed exile, despite a pending warrant for his arrest. Carles Puigdemont is the figurehead of hardline separatist party Junts, and led Catalonia between 2016 and 2017 before fleeing Spain following a referendum on independence deemed illegal by the judiciary.\n\nIt remains unclear how he plans to return to the country and enter the regional parliament while evading police. Jordi Turull, secretary-general of Junts, told broadcaster 324 on Tuesday that he would call for the leadership vote to be suspended if Puigdemont is detained, as \"it cannot take place in normal conditions\" without him present.\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, will kick off on Thursday at 10 a.m. local time (0800 GMT), according to the parliamentary speaker. EXCLUDED FROM AMNESTY\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others, who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them. A source close to Puigdemont told Reuters he had \"no doubt\" that the former leader - who lived in Belgium between 2017 and 2024 while serving as a member of the European Parliament and has in recent months been based in southern France - would be arrested upon re-entering Spain and brought before the Supreme Court in Madrid.\n\nPolitical scientist Toni Rodon of Barcelona's Pompeu Fabra University told Reuters that Puidgemont had possibly decided to come back because of the personal toll of living in exile. \"The amnesty has changed the game play, and the other strategy he can pursue can be more useful inside the Spanish borders even if he ends up in jail,\" Rodon added.\n\nIn an open letter posted on his X account on Friday, Puigdemont described Spain's efforts to detain him as a \"hybrid coup\", adding \"if they succeed, I imagine what awaits me and know what I must do\". ERC spokesperson Raquel Sans acknowledged on Tuesday that Puigdemont's arrest could delay the vote for a new Catalan leader.\n\nPolice will try to arrest Puigdemont before he reaches the heavily guarded parliament building in Barcelona, but are also authorised to enter if needed, El Periodico newspaper reported, citing police sources. Officers were also monitoring the sewer system in case it was used for alternative entry routes.\n\nIn 2011, then-leader Artur Mas was forced to access the building's rooftop by helicopter after it was surrounded by nearly 1,000 anti-austerity activists protesting against budget cuts.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", {"uri": "8265130432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:02:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:02:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/business/2024/08/08/excatalan-leader-gives-police-the-slip-on-his-return-to-spain-after-nearly-7-years-as-a-fugitive/", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader gives police the slip on his return to Spain after nearly 7 years as a fugitive - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW BARCELONA, Spain (AP) - Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated separatist who seven years after fleeing Spain sensationally returned to the country despite an outstanding arrest warrant. Puigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on a day that Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president. The 61-year-old fugitive initially lived in Belgium after bolting Spain in 2017, but his latest place of residence wasn't known. Puigdemont kept his travel plans secret before setting out to the wealthy Catalan region in northeastern Spain. He gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him. After his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, Puigdemont went into an adjacent marquee tent. There, he hurried out of an exit and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure. Authorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Puigdemont was expected to go afterward. Once Puigdemont had slipped away, roadside police units checked vehicles across the city of around 1.6 million people in an effort to nab him. The checks snarled city traffic. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighboring France. Puigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway. Those events triggered a political crisis that roiled Spain for months. Puigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police, stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament. Local police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls. Meanwhile, Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech. Addressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\"\u009d on the Catalan separatist movement. \"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\"\u009d Puigdemont said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\u009d He added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\u009d The turn of events was likely to bring political recriminations. The leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-center coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Puigdemont's return. Alberto N\u00c3\u00ba\u00c3\u00b1ez Feij\u00c3\u00b3o posted on X that Puigdemont's reappearance was an \"unbearable humiliation\"\u009d that damaged Spain's reputation. Spain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president Thursday. Speaking to Catalan lawmakers before the vote, Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favor of independence and those against it. Puigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain - a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government. A contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal. But the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues the pardon doesn't apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Puigdemont had previously been charged with. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention if he is arrested. ___ Barry Hatton reported from Lisbon, Portugal.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine {"uri": "8265024803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:59:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:59:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:58:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/08/08/catalan-ex-leader-puigdemont-back-in-spain-despite-arrest-warrant_6711468_4.html", "title": "Catalan ex-leader Puigdemont back in Spain despite arrest warrant", "body": "Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain over his role in a failed 2017 independence bid for the wealthy region, returned on Thursday, August 8, after seven years on the run and despite a pending arrest warrant. Puigdemont shouted \"Long live a free Catalonia!\" as he climbed onto a stage in Barcelona to address thousands gathered near the Catalan regional parliament which is set to elect a new leader later in the day. \"I have come here to remind you that we are still here,\" he said as many in the crowd waved red, yellow and blue Catalan independence flags.\n\nAfter his brief address, Puigdemont appeared to head toward the Catalan parliament but the assembly began an investiture vote to pick a new leader for the region without him being present. A small group of protesters gathered nearby waving Spanish flags and holding signs that read \"Catalonia is Spain\" in a demonstration organized by far-right party Vox.\n\nPuigdemont's dramatic return came just days after Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's Socialists struck a deal with moderate Catalan separatist party ERC - which competes with Puigdemont's more hardline JxCAT - to make the Socialist candidate, Salvador Illa, the next head of the Catalan regional government. The Socialists won the most seats in a regional election in May but failed to get a majority and the support of the ERC is crucial. If a new Catalan regional government is not formed by August 26, fresh elections will be held in October.\n\nPuigdemont led the regional government of Catalonia in 2017 when it pushed ahead with an independence referendum despite a court ban, which was followed by a short-lived declaration of independence. He fled the country shortly after the independence bid to avoid prosecution and has since lived in Belgium and more recently France.\n\nWhile Spain's parliament in May passed an amnesty law for those involved in the botched secession bid, the Supreme Court ruled on July 1 that the measure would not fully apply to Puigdemont. In a video posted on social network X on Wednesday to announce his imminent return to attend the investiture vote, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a long persecution\". \"This challenge {"uri": "2024-08-446839523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "11:42:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T11:42:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T07:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2024-08-07/fugitive-ex-catalan-leader-plans-return-to-spain-despite-threat-of-arrest-over-failed-secession-bid", "title": "Fugitive Ex-Catalan Leader Plans Return to Spain Despite Threat of Arrest Over Failed Secession Bid", "body": "BARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who fled Spain after organizing an illegal independence referendum in the wealthy Spanish region nearly seven years ago, announced that he plans to return home on Thursday despite the likelihood he will be arrested.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, who fled to Belgium after the breakaway bid in October 2017 quickly collapsed, said Wednesday that he would attend an event organized by his political party Together for Catalonia (Junts) near Barcelona's regional parliament building, hours before a new regional government takes office.\n\nHe didn't say when or how he would arrive in Spain. The political event in Barcelona is likely to gather many of Puigdemont's supporters.\n\nThe Mossos D'Esquadra, the regional police in Catalonia, say that they intend to obey court orders to arrest Puigdemont, if he does return.\n\nIn his announcement on YouTube, Puigdemont recognized that he \"cannot attend freely\" the scheduled parliamentary session and accused authorities of \"a long persecution\" over the unsuccessful breakaway attempt.\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he said.\n\nPuigdemont's return is likely to generate renewed political tension over the smoldering issue of Catalan independence. The failed secession attempt triggered a protracted constitutional crisis in Spain.\n\nPuigdemont and his supporters have long taken a confrontational and at times provocative stance toward Spain's central authorities, especially the Madrid-based government.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Illa to become the next regional president in an investiture debate Thursday, scheduled shortly after Puigdemont's first planned event and which will take place amid tight security.\n\nPuigdemont, who is wanted on charges of misuse of public funds, among other offenses, during the secession attempt, has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in northeast Spain -- a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear Puigdemont and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Puigdemont could be placed in pretrial detention.\n\nPuigdemont's escape from Spain became the stuff of legend among his followers, and a huge source of embarrassment for Spanish law enforcement. He is a celebrated figurehead for many Catalans who want to break away from the rest of Spain.\n\nEarlier this year, Puigdemont denied that he had hidden in a car trunk to avoid detection while slipping across the border after the referendum. The subsequent legal crackdown landed several of his cohorts in prison until Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez's government pardoned them.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8265234247", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:06:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:06:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:05:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-wanted-ex-catalan-separatist-leader-carles-puigdemont-evades-capture/", "title": "Wanted ex-Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont evades capture on chaotic return to Spain", "body": "Former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont defied an arrest warrant to appear at a rally in Spain's Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile and then vanished, sparking a frantic search by police to apprehend him.\n\nAmid a heavy police presence, Puigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital from a platform near the Catalan parliament, telling them he aimed to revive the independence drive that plunged Spain into political crisis in 2017.\n\n\"They thought they'd be celebrating my arrest and they thought that this punishment would dissuade us, and you,\" he said. \"Well, they are wrong.\"\n\nWhen he had finished speaking Puigdemont went backstage, after which police and media were unable to locate him. The hunt for his whereabouts created traffic chaos in Barcelona and near the border with France as police set up roadblocks and searched car boots.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since.\n\nHe faces an arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nHis supporters hope his return will rekindle enthusiasm for the Catalan independence cause, which lost support in recent years. Senior officials of Puigdemont's Junts party, including parliament speaker Josep Rull, and members of the moderate separatist Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya which currently runs the regional government led a march to the Catalan parliament after the rally.\n\nA debate to swear in Socialist Salvador Illa as Catalonia\u00b4s new president, ending a decade of separatist rule, began amid confusion and speculation about Puigdemont's whereabouts. A Catalan Interior Ministry spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" he said.\n\nA Supreme Court spokesperson declined to comment on Puigdemont's disappearance in Barcelona. A government spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment, nor did Puigdemont\u00b4s lawyer.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont had announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\nHis arrest could jeopardize the national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nIn the morning, a crowd of thousands had gathered near the parliament to welcome him and hear him speak.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\" The vote to invest Socialist Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, began an hour later.\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe embezzlement charges were related to the 2017 independence referendum ruled illegal by the Spanish courts.\n\nPuigdemont insists the vote was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender', 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, risk his life to move the country forward,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont said on Wednesday he was returning after seven years in self-imposed exile to Spain, where he would likely be arrested over his role in the region's 2017 independence bid.\n\nHis arrest and potential imprisonment before facing trial could unleash fresh turmoil in Catalonia and scupper the fragile Socialist-led coalition ruling Spain, which relies on Puigdemont's hardline Junts party to pass legislation.\n\nAs a condition set by Junts for its legislative support for Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's government, Spain's parliament in May approved an amnesty law aimed at allowing Puigdemont's return from Belgium by cancelling legal proceedings against hundreds of separatists involved in Catalonia's 2017 illegal referendum.\n\nBut Spain's Supreme Court said last month the amnesty should not apply to a charge of embezzlement against Puigdemont and uphold an arrest warrant he faces.\n\nStill, Puigdemont said he remained committed to being present when the Catalan parliament would be scheduled to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May in which Puigdemont finished second.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont said he would keep his word and be in Barcelona on Thursday.\n\n\"I have started the return trip from exile,\" he said in a video posted on X, adding he intended to attend Thursday's session which is poised to appoint Socialist Salvador Illa as the new Catalan president, ending over a decade of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont's supporters plan to gather and welcome him on Thursday morning on a Barcelona avenue near the regional parliament, setting the stage for a potentially dramatic arrest witnessed by reporters and bystanders.\n\nNeither Puigdemont nor Junts on Wednesday said whether he had already entered Spain.\n\nIn the video message, Puigdemont said his arrest would be illegal and arbitrary.\n\nHis arrest would end to close to seven years avoiding Spanish justice. If the judge in charge of his case issues a pre-trial imprisonment, Puigdemont is expected to appeal for his release to Spain's Constitutional Court, which has a majority of progressive-leaning judges.\n\n(Reporting by Joan Faus; editing by Charlie Devereux)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8265168372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:24:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:24:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:23:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/spain-catalonia-vote-carles-puigdemont-fugitive-b2593123.html", "title": "Police hunt for fugitive separatist Catalan leader Puigdemont as he returns to Spain", "body": "Catalan police are hunting for fugitive Catalonia separatist Carles Puigdemont after he dramatically returned to Spain for the first time in seven years to address a crowd of thousands before vanishing again.\n\nThe 61-year-old, a former president of the Catalonia region, climbed a stage to give a short speech near the Catalan parliament in Barcelona to thousands of followers who had shown up with independence flags and signs showing his face.\n\n\"Today, many thought they'd be celebrating my arrest, and thought that this punishment would dissuade us - and you,\" he said.\n\n\"Today I came to remind them that we are still here! We are still here because we have no right to quit.\"\n\nMr Puigdemont fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He faces an arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nHis supporters hope his return will rekindle enthusiasm for the Catalan independence cause, which has lost support in recent years. \"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Mr Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nAfter his speech, Mr Puigdemont was swiftly whisked through the crowd by members of his Together for Catalonia (Junts) party but was then nowhere to be seen among the politicians who later reached parliament.\n\nThe Catalan Interior Department confirmed he is on the run again and says they have set up roadblocks in a bid to arrest him. Police were stopping and searching vehicles heading towards the French border and there are traffic controls around the city centre following reports that Puigdemont was seen leaving in a car. The searches created traffic chaos in Barcelona and near the border.\n\nA Catalan Interior Ministry spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" she said. \"I can confirm roadblocks have been set up to find him.\"\n\nThursday's parliamentary session is set to see socialist Salvador Illa to be appointed as the new Catalan president, ending more than 10 years of separatist governments in the northeastern Spanish region.\n\nMr Puigdemont's return poses a direct challenge to Spain's judicial authorities and its delicate coalition government, risking a resurgence of tensions between Catalan separatists and Madrid.\n\nIn a video released on Wednesday, outlining his plan to return, Mr Puigdemont complained about being unable to \"attend freely\" and of \"a long persecution.\"\n\nHe said: \"That I can attend the parliament should be normal. That to do so risks an arrest that would be arbitrary and illegal is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have the duty to denounce and fight.\"\n\nIt was not immediately clear how authorities will proceed if Mr Puigdemont is arrested. Detaining him could jeopardise the national Socialist-led coalition government's fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nA contentious amnesty Bill could potentially clear him and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing over the illegal 2017 ballot.\n\nBut the Bill, approved by Spain's parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, leaving uncertainty about what crimes would be pardoned. Mr Puigdemont could initially be placed in pre-trial detention if he is arrested.\n\nThe former Catalan leader's return threatened to complicate a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC).\n\nThat deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Mr Illa to become the next regional president\n\n\"We had to see how the state allowed this criminal to hold a rally,\" Ignacio Garriga, secretary general of the far-right Vox party, told reporters outside the Catalan parliament. \"We don't understand why he hasn't been arrested yet\".", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8265341306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:12:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:12:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:11:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dw.com/en/spain-police-launch-manhunt-after-defiant-puigdemont-speech/a-69883930", "title": "Spain: Catalan separatist Puigdemont returns, faces arrest", "body": "A major manhunt was underway on Thursday after separatist leader Carles Puigdemont appeared before supporters in Barcelona.\n\nPolice set up checkpoints on all major roads leading out of the Catalan capital, with officers searching vehicles. Puigdemont, who is the subject of an arrest warrant over his role in a failed independence bid, returned to Spain for the first time in seven years.\n\nSpanish police have detained a colleague suspected of helping the separatist leader escape into hiding in Barcelona, local media reported.\n\nThe officer was reported to have provided a white car in which Puigdemont is said to have escaped after delivering his message.\n\nPuigdemont had appeared on stage surrounded by officials of his hardline separatist party Junts to address thousands of cheering supporters in Catalan.\n\n\"Despite them wanting to damage us, I have come here today to remind them that we are still here,\" he said.\n\n\"We don't have the right to give up because the right to self-determination belongs to the Catalan people.\"\n\n\"It will never be a crime to hold a referendum.\"\n\nPuigdemont was planning to attend Thursday's session of the regional parliament, in which a new regional leader was set to be sworn in after a May election that saw Puigdemont's party finishing second.\n\n\"That in order to do so I would risk an arbitrary and illegal detention is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have a duty to denounce and fight against,\" he said in a video posted on social media.\n\nThe 61-year-old has dedicated his career to Catalan independence, but his party's largely uncompromising approach has caused conflict with Spain's central government and other separatist parties.\n\nHe led Catalonia's regional government in 2017 when it proceeded with an independence referendum despite a court ban. This was followed by a short-lived declaration of independence.\n\nPuigdemont, who fled to Belgium after a Spanish police crackdown, faces charges of embezzlement for his part in the attempt to separate Catalonia from the rest of Spain.\n\nThe Catalan government says about 2.3 million people, some 43% of eligible voters, took part in the referendum and that just over 92% voted to break away from Spain.\n\nHowever, many people opposed to independence boycotted the ballot.\n\nSpain's parliament in May passed an amnesty law for those involved in the secession bid, but the country's Supreme Court last month said this did not apply to those accused of misusing public funds, a charge leveled at the Junts leader.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez agreed to the amnesty law in exchange for Junts support for a fragile minority government in the Spanish parliament. That sparked large street protests organized by the far-right against the measure.\n\nSanchez faces opposition from the right and also parts of his own Socialist party over a proposal to allow Catalonia full control of the taxes collected in the region.", "source": {"uri": "dw.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deutsche Welle"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
