{"uri": "8260172646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:24:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:24:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:23:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-announces-stormy-return-to-spain-amid-heightened-political-tensions/", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont announces 'stormy' return to Spain amid heightened political tensions", "body": "Former Catalan president, Charles Puigdemont, says he plans to return to Spain for the inauguration of new regional head, socialist Salvador Illa, despite facing likely arrest amid heightened political tensions.\n\nEven with the approval of the controversial amnesty law, which pardons the illegal actions of some 300 Catalan separatist leaders and activists between 2011 and 2023, the crime of embezzlement committed by members of Puigdemont's former government - including himself - during the illegal independence referendum in October 2017, remains outside this ruling.\n\nPuigdemont, the former president of the Generalitat (regional executive), and leader in exile of the right-wing separatist formation Together for Catalonia (JxCat) has a national arrest warrant.\n\nIf he decides to cross the border from the French region of Vallespir, where he currently resides, after moving there from Waterloo (Belgium), he is most likely to face arrest.\n\nDespite this risk, Puigdemont reiterated on his X account, his intention to return to Spain to attend Illa's inauguration ceremony, which could take place Friday (9 August), or this weekend, as reported by Euractiv\u00b4s partner EFE.\n\n\"I imagine what is awaiting me (to be arrested) but I know what I must do,\" Puigdemont stated while taking it for granted that he will be imprisoned, \"who knows for how long,\" lamented Puigdemont .\n\nIn response, president of JxCat, Laura Borr\u00e0s demanded on Monday, that Illa officially states his response if Puigdemont crosses the Franco-Spanish border.\n\n\"The question is: what will Salvador Illa do if in his inauguration debate, if President Puigdemont is arrested because Spanish judges do not apply the (amnesty) law that his party (PSOE) and his government approved?\" asked Borr\u00e0s.\n\nSince the snap election held in Catalonia on 12 May, political developments in this prosperous region of northeastern Spain have developed rapidly.\n\nIlla, a former health minister and leader of Catalonia's Socialist Party, though winning the regional elections did not gain enough votes to form a majority. Therefore in recent weeks he has been negotiating around the clock with political parties to gain power.\n\nGiven that Illa's party, the PSC, does not fully share a separatist ideology, he and Spanish Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez, (PSOE/S&D), have been forced to make generous concessions to the closest ideological party with whom they can work with: the left-wing separatist Republican Left of Catalonia (ERC).\n\nThe stability of Sanchez's progressive executive and the left-wing platform Sumar, now depends on both the ERC's seven lawmakers in the Spanish Parliament, and the seven of Puigdemont's faction.\n\nThe separatists' very high price\n\nJust as S\u00e1nchez had to a few months ago promise Puigdemont and the ERC an amnesty law, in addition to broader concessions to strengthen Catalan's self-government. Illa has had to also follow the Spanish prime minister, agreeing to what Madrid euphemistically calls financiaci\u00f3n singular, or a special financing model for Catalonia.\n\nThis yet-to-be-finalised concept, however, has come as a bitter pill to swallow for those provinces governed by Partido Popular (PP/EPP). Their regional presidents warned that - if implemented, it will create \"first and second class regions,\" undermining the principles of equity and solidarity among regions.\n\nSpain is highly decentralised, with some experts describing it as quasi-federal, with 17 'Autonomous Communities' having power over providing key public services, including housing, education and health.\n\nTherefore, Spain has two basic models for financing regions.\n\nOne is called the 'common' system, in which covers almost all regions, including the Canary Islands and the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla (in Northern Africa).\n\nThe other is called the \"foral regime\" (regimen foral), which includes the Basque Country and Navarre (north), which have special fiscal privileges for historical reasons.\n\nIn addition to theses transfers from the central government, regions can raise additional money from their own resources, including numerous local taxes, or applying for EU grants.\n\nThe main difference between the two models, is that in the 'common regime' system it is the central administration that collects a large part of the taxes and distributes them among the regions, on the basis of a principle of solidarity between the richer and poorer regions.\n\nBut in the \"foral regime\" (r\u00e9gimen foral), it is the regions that collect the taxes to finance their investments, paying a contribution to the central state.\n\nAlthough the agreement signed 30 July between S\u00e1nchez and the ERC, facilitating Illa's inauguration, includes a significant improvement in transfers from Madrid to Catalonia, including the funding for the regional police and research and development, the separatist party is now demanding much more.\n\nThis \"price to be paid\" by S\u00e1nchez seems likely to be very high, as behind the euphemism of \"singular financing\" hides the demand that Catalonia, a region with 7.6 million people, should keep all the taxes it collects in the future.\n\nIf the proposal goes ahead, many experts warn that it could spell the end of the current financing system, which is based on equity and solidarity between regions, in favour of a variable-geometry or \"multi-speed\" model if the region of Catalonia is able to collect all its taxes in the future.", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "EurActiv.com"}, {"uri": "8265013917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:52:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:52:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:51:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/puigdemont-returns-to-spain-as-a-free-man-condemning-his-repression/", "title": "Puigdemont returns to Spain as a \"free man\", condemning his \"repression\"", "body": "Former Catalan president Carles Puigdemont returned to Spain from southern France, and before some 3,500 separatist supporters, who gathered in Barcelona on Thursday (8 Aug), lamented his \"repression\" of which he had been a victim since 2017, despite being free of the police force set up to capture him.\n\n\"Today I have come here to remind you that we are still here because we do not have the right to resign (of his pro-independence ideas),\" Puigdemont declared, Euractiv\u00b4s partner EFE reported.\n\n\"For seven years they have been persecuting us for wanting to listen to the voice of the people of Catalonia. Seven years ago they began a harsh repression that has led us to prison and exile, this has affected the lives of thousands and thousands of people, for the fact of being pro-independence, sometimes just for the fact of speaking Catalan, and they have turned the fact of being Catalan into something suspicious,\" Puigdemont denounced.\n\nMuch anticipated by the Spanish and international media, Puigdemont, leader of the right-wing separatist party Together for Catalonia (JxCat), announced a few days ago that he intended to enter the Catalan parliament in Barcelona on Thursday.\n\nThe reason is the inauguration of Salvador Illa, leader of the Socialist Party of Catalonia (PSC), as the new president of the regional executive (Generalitat).\n\n\"Today, many will celebrate my arrest and think that the scorn will deter us, that it is worth breaking even a law passed by your Parliament to make a mockery of me. But they are wrong. And in their mistake they will once again drag down the credibility of Spanish democracy, although we know that this matters very little to them,\" Puigdemont added.\n\nAccording to the JxCat leader, \"it is not, nor was it, nor it will ever be a crime to hold a referendum and obey the mandate of the Parliament of Catalonia,\" he stressed referring to the illegal pro-independence referendum of 1 October 2017.\n\nHowever, according to state broadcaster RTVE, Puigdemont did not enter Catalan Parliament, nor - as of 11.00 am - was there any news that he had been arrested.\n\nCatalan regional police has deployed an extensive operation - Operation Jaula (Cage, in Spanish) - throughout Barcelona in an attempt to arrest the separatist leader, EFE reported.\n\nAlthough Illa won the snap regional elections on 12 May, he did not gather a sufficient majority to govern alone. To win key parliamentary support from the left-wing separatist Republican Left of Catalonia (ERC) party, he was forced to make concessions, including more self-governing powers for Catalonia.\n\nDespite the amnesty law promoted by Spain's Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez (PSOE/S&D), which pardons crimes committed by separatist activists between 2011 and 2023, the crime of embezzlement - and personal enrichment in Puigdemont's case - is not covered by the amensty.\n\nPuigdemont is still under a Spanish national arrest warrant for that crime.\n\nBoth JxCat and the ERC each have seven lawmakers in the Spanish national parliament, on whose support the S\u00e1nchez coalition government with the left-wing Sumar platform depends.\n\nPuigdemont fled Spain in 2017, going into self-exile initially in Waterloo, near Brussels, until April this year, then he settled in the south of France, from where he crossed the border into Spain.", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.com", {"uri": "2024-08-447736692", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:19:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:19:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:17:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.politico.eu/article/carles-puigdemont-arrested-separatist-barcelona-catalan-parliament/", "title": "Facing arrest, defiant separatist leader Carles Puigdemont returns to Barcelona", "body": "Police forces are under orders to take the former Catalan regional president into custody.\n\nBARCELONA, Spain -- Seven years after fleeing Spain to avoid arrest, Carles Puigdemont reappeared in Barcelona in front of hundreds of cheering supporters on Thursday outside the Catalan parliament.\n\nPuigdemont, the figurehead of the region's separatist movement, appeared on a stage next to the city's Triumphal Arch. Supporters formed a human barrier around him. The politician is subject to an active arrest warrant and police forces are under orders to detain him if they see him.\n\n\"Despite all the efforts to do us harm, I have come here today to remind them that we are still here and that we do not have to give up,\" Puigdemont told the crowd. \"Long live Free Catalonia!\"\n\nThe former Catalan president announced his intention to return to Barcelona on Wednesday, saying he intended to be back in Barcelona for a vote on Socialist Salvador Illa becoming regional president, which would put an end to 14 years of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont intends to march to the Catalan parliament accompanied by his supporters. Police forces have sealed off the building and are guarding the entrances.\n\nExpectation was high ahead of Puigdemont's promised appearance. In the hour before the event's scheduled start at 9 a.m., booming music and large screens recounted the past seven years of the Catalan leader's political trials and tribulations.\n\nAttendees chanted \"Puigdemont, our president!\" and \"independence!\" while waiting for his arrival, with some wearing masks depicting the former Catalan president's face.\n\n\"I'm not happy. Because I would have liked to avoid this unpleasant situation of seeing him taken by the police. I'd love to see him make a grand entrance,\" one supporter in the crowd told POLITICO. \"But now I am afraid that it will be a humiliating situation, maybe they will take him to Madrid just like prey in a major hunt.\"\n\nShould Puigdemont be arrested, he will likely be transferred to Madrid to appear before the Supreme Court, when a judge will decide whether to send him to prison until trial, or release him on bail.\n\nPuigdemont hadn't set foot on Spanish soil since 2017 when authorities ordered his arrest for organizing the region's illegal independence referendum. An arrest warrant in his name remained in force -- leaving his only option being to get back into Spain covertly.\n\nIn 2017, he\u202fevaded the Spanish authorities\u202fby sneaking out of Spain across the border, finding refuge in Waterloo, just outside Brussels. From there he led the Catalan independence movement's presence on the international stage, by becoming a Member of the European Parliament in 2019.", "source": {"uri": "politico.eu", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-447878018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:31:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:31:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:28:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20240808-catalan-separatist-leader-puigdemont-returns-spain-despite-arrest-warrant", "title": "Catalan separatist leader Puigdemont returns to Spain despite arrest warrant", "body": "Puigdemont shouted \"Long live a free Catalonia!\" as he climbed onto a stage in Barcelona to address thousands gathered near the Catalan regional parliament which is set to elect a new leader later in the day.\n\n\"I have come here to remind you that we are still here,\" he said as many in the crowd waved red, yellow and blue Catalan independence flags.\n\nAfter his brief address, Puigdemont appeared to head towards the nearby Catalan parliament but the assembly began an investiture vote to pick a new leader for the region without him being present.\n\nIt was not immediately clear where he was.\n\nNuria Pujol, a woman in her fifties who came to Barcelona from the Alt Penedes region to see Puigdemont, called him \"a very noble person\".\n\n\"The only one who believes in independence and has not stopped believing,\" she added.\n\nA small group of protesters gathered nearby waving Spanish flags and holding signs that read \"Catalonia is Spain\" in a demonstration organised by far-right party Vox.\n\n'Long persecution'\n\nPuigdemont's dramatic return came just days after Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's Socialists struck a deal with moderate Catalan separatist party ERC -- which competes with Puigdemont's more hardline JxCAT -- to make the Socialist candidate, Salvador Illa, the next head of the Catalan regional government.\n\nThe Socialists won the most seats in a regional election in May but failed to get a majority and the support of the ERC is crucial.\n\nIf a new Catalan regional government is not formed by August 26, fresh elections will be held in October.\n\nPuigdemont led the regional government of Catalonia in 2017 when it pushed ahead with an independence referendum despite a court ban, which was followed by a short-lived declaration of independence.\n\nHe fled Spain shortly after the independence bid to avoid prosecution and has since lived in Belgium and more recently France.\n\nWhile Spain's parliament in May passed an amnesty law for those involved in the botched secession bid, the Supreme Court ruled on July 1 that the measure would not fully apply to Puigdemont.\n\nIn a video posted on social network X on Wednesday to announce his imminent return to attend the investiture vote, Puigdemont accused Spanish authorities of \"a long persecution\".\n\n\"This challenge must be answered and confronted,\" he added.\n\nPath to independence?\n\nSanchez agreed to the amnesty law in exchange for JxCAT's crucial support in Spain's parliament for his fragile minority government, sparking huge street protests against the measure organised by the right.\n\nHe is now facing opposition from parts of his own Socialist party as well as the right over a proposal to give Catalonia full control of the taxes collected in the region.\n\nThe measure was promised to the ERC in exchange for the party's support for Illa in Thursday's investiture vote.\n\nThe proposal has for decades been one of the main demands of Catalan independence parties but critics argue it would deprive the central state of a substantial source of revenue. It still must be approved by Spain's national parliament.\n\nA similar system already exists in Spain's northern Basque Country, which also has an active independence movement.\n\nIf Illa passes Thursday's investiture vote, he will be the first head of Catalonia's regional government who does not come from the separatist camp since 2010.\n\nThe former health minister has defended the tax agreement made with the ERC, saying they are \"in favour of all Catalans\".\n\n\"They are agreements to improve our financing without harming anyone and maintaining criteria of solidarity,\" he said after securing the ERC's support.\n\nBut former Socialist deputy prime minister Alfonso Guerra has warned the tax agreement opens \"a path towards a federal system and the independence of {"uri": "8265519313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "15:13:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T15:13:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:09:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/police-hunt-catalan-leader-return-150127776.html", "title": "Police hunt for Catalan leader after return from exile", "body": "Spanish police have launched a manhunt for Carles Puidgemont, the Catalan separatist leader after he returned from exile, gave a speech in front of thousands and then disappeared into the crowd.\n\nMr Puigdemont has been living in Belgium for almost seven years since he fled Spain in October 2017. He left to avoid prison for spearheading an illegal attempt to create an independent Catalonia.\n\nThe 61-year-old spoke in Catalan to a crowd of supporters under Barcelona's L'Arc de Triomf monument on Thursday and was expected to walk to the nearby Catalan parliament to attend a debate on the selection of a new president for the region.\n\n\"We're still here! We're still here!\" Mr Puigdemont said as he criticised what he called Spain's \"ferocious repression\" of the separatist movement.\n\nPro-independence supporters and fellow members of Mr Puigdemont's Junts party had assembled close to the stage to escort the former Catalan president through the crowds.\n\nBut Mr Puigdemont vanished in the melee.\n\nCatalonia's police force had orders to arrest Mr Puigdemont, who is accused of embezzling public funds in the run-up to the unlawful referendum and subsequent declaration of independence in Oct 2017.\n\nNine people, including several members of Mr Puigdemont's Catalan government, spent more than three years in prison for their part in the illegal secession bid. They were then pardoned by the Left-wing government of Pedro S\u00e1nchez, the Spanish Prime Minister, in 2021.\n\nCatalonia's Mossos d'esquadra police has set up a search operation to try to locate Mr Puigdemont, including checkpoints on major road exits from Barcelona.\n\nSpain's conservative and Right-wing opposition parties reacted with fury to the latest escape by the former European MP, who has previously been arrested in Germany and Italy - without being extradited to Spain.\n\nAlberto N\u00fa\u00f1ez Feij\u00f3o, leader of the conservative People's Party, said the events in Barcelona on Thursday morning were \"an unbearable humiliation\" and accused Mr S\u00e1nchez of bearing \"ultimate responsibility\".\n\nThe hard-Right Vox party described as \"a bloody disgrace\" that \"a coupmonger and fugitive from justice is able to enter Spain without anyone stopping him\".\n\nCatalonia's parliament is currently debating whether to elect Salvador Illa, an ally of Mr S\u00e1nchez, as the region's new president after his Catalan Socialist Party won the most seats in an election held in May.\n\nMr S\u00e1nchez's minority Spanish government crucially won the support of Mr Puigdemont after negotiating and approving an amnesty law scrapping criminal procedures against Catalan separatists.\n\nIt stated that Mr Puigdemont and others should not face charges if they did not make personal financial gain.\n\nBut in a controversial decision, the Supreme Court ruled that the amnesty did not cover the offence of embezzling public funds. It argued that the unlawful use of public money to organise a referendum constituted a personal benefit for Mr Puigdemont.\n\nThe former regional leader insists the vote was not illegal and therefore the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\n\"A country where amnesty laws do not [mean] amnesty has a democratic problem,\" Mr Puigdemont said in his speech before he left the stage and melted into {"uri": "2024-08-447812461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "08:32:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T08:32:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T08:06:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://tass.com/world/1826533", "title": "Fugitive Catalan separatist leader returns to Spain, defying arrest warrant", "body": "The politician intends to attend a debate in the region's parliament on whether to approve the candidacy of Socialist Salvador Illa to lead the autonomous community\n\nMADRID, August 8. /TASS/. Former Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont has returned to Spain for the first time since fleeing the country about seven years ago, according to a broadcast on the politician's YouTube channel.\n\nThe ex-leader still has an outstanding warrant for his arrest in the region. He appeared in the Catalan capital, Barcelona, where hundreds of the politician's supporters gathered to greet him. Some of those who came brought pictures of Puigdemont and esteladas (the unofficial flag of the Catalan states, which is the symbol of the region's independence supporters). The politician intends to attend a debate in the region's parliament on whether to approve the candidacy of Socialist Salvador Illa to lead the autonomous community. Many speculate that Puigdemont will be be arrested if he shows.\n\nAhead of his return, the former Catalan leader said that his arrest would be illegal.\n\nIn June, Spain enacted an amnesty law for those involved in the Catalan separatist process. However, Spain's Supreme Court did not grant amnesty to Puigdemont and left in force the national warrant for his arrest. The Supreme Court deemed that embezzling public funds, the crime which the politician is accused of, does not fall under amnesty.\n\nThe 61-year-old Puigdemont headed the Catalan government from 2016 to 2017. Under his leadership, the region held a separatist referendum on October 1, 2017, which Madrid initially called illegal. The politician was removed from office by a decision of the Spanish government, which then resorted to the unprecedented measure of partially stripping the region of its right to self-governance.\n\nPuigdemont later fled Spain to Belgium. The Spanish judicial authorities failed to secure his extradition, even though Puigdemont was detained in Germany and Italy. His arrival appeared unhindered by police.\n\nYesterday, Mr Puigdemont announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending today's session of the Catalan parliament to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Mr Puigdemont's party finished second.\n\nWe need your consent to load this comcast-player contentWe use comcast-player to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. Please review their details and accept them to load the content.Manage Preferences\n\n\"That in order to do so I would risk an arbitrary and illegal detention is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have a duty to denounce and fight against,\" he said in a video posted on social media.\n\nThe building in central Barcelona housing the regional parliament was fenced off this morning and surrounded by officers of the Catalan police force, the Mossos d'Esquadra.\n\nMr Puigdemont, 61, a former journalist, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since.\n\nHis party had called on supporters to give him a mass welcome at the nearby Arc de Triomf monument, where a stage with TV screens had been set up. Other Catalan separatist parties and civil society groups said they would also attend.\n\nFar-right Vox was set to hold a counter-protest outside the parliament. Its secretary general, Ignacio Garriga, said that \"we will not tolerate the humiliation of seeing a criminal and fugitive from justice enter parliament\".\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, is slated to kick off at 9am Irish time.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Mr Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe court said the three obtained personal gain by charging the expenses of holding the independence referendum deemed illegal by the Spanish judiciary to the {"uri": "8264845311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "08:12:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T08:12:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T08:05:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13722589/Catalan-separatist-Puigdemont-faces-arrest-supporters-cheer-return-Spain.html", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont faces arrest as supporters cheer his...", "body": "Separatist leader appears in Catalan capital Barcelona\n\n*\n\nCarles Puigdemont returns to Spain after self-imposed exile\n\n*\n\nThousands of supporters gather waving flags\n\n*\n\nPuigdemont risks arrest due to outstanding warrant\n\n(Recasts lead, adds colour)\n\nBy Joan Faus\n\nMADRID, Aug 8 (Reuters) -\n\nDefying an arrest warrant against him, former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont appeared in the Spanish city of Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile, as he sought to reignite a flagging independence movement.\n\nPuigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital, who had gathered near the regional parliament, waving Catalan independence flags and holding up signs showing his face.\n\nThe politician, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He is now likely to be detained over an outstanding arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\n\"That in order to do so I would risk an arbitrary and illegal detention is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have a duty to denounce and fight against,\" he said in a video posted on social media.\n\nHis arrest could delay the swearing-in of a Socialist government in Catalonia and jeopardise the national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nThe building in central Barcelona housing the regional parliament was fenced off and surrounded by officers of the Catalan police force, the Mossos d'Esquadra.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\nAmong the crowd were top officials from Junts, including the regional parliament's speaker, Josep Rull.\n\nRISK OF PRISON\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nFar-right Vox was set to hold a counter-protest outside the parliament. Its secretary general, Ignacio Garriga, said on X that \"we will not tolerate the humiliation of seeing a criminal and fugitive from justice enter parliament\".\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, was slated to kick off at 10 a.m. (0800 GMT).\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive, which has been losing support in recent years.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nPuigdemont insists the referendum was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender', 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, putting at risk his life to move the country forward,\" she said.\n\n(Reporting by David Latona, Joan Faus, Horaci Garcia and Michael Gore; writing by David Latona and Charlie Devereux; editing by Sandra Maler and Sharon Singleton)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-447738790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:24:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:24:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:11:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/08/08/catalan-leader-puigdemont-return-spain-exile/", "title": "Catalan leader Puigdemont returns to Spain after 7 years as a fugitive", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nCatalan leader Carles Puigdemont, who had been living in self-declared exile since staging an unsuccessful bid for the region's independence, reemerged in Spain on Thursday, nearly seven years after he fled the country.\n\nIt was unclear how, or exactly when, he had returned to Spain. He appeared on Thursday on a stage, addressing a welcome rally in Barcelona called by his separatist party.\n\nHis return represents a direct challenge to Spain's judicial authorities and the country's fragile coalition government, as it threatens to renew tensions between Catalan separatists and Madrid.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, had been based primarily in Belgium since the 2017 breakaway referendum. He was a member of the European Parliament from 2019 until last month. He successfully avoided extradition, including after being detained in Italy and in Germany.\n\nBut this week he announced his intention to show up at Catalonia's parliament in Barcelona for the scheduled induction of a political rival as the new regional president.\n\nAt the rally of his supporters Thursday, which began shortly before the parliamentary sessions, some people carried masks of Puigdemont's face.\n\nThe regional police had warned that they intended to obey orders to arrest him. In anticipation, they sealed off most entrances to the park where the parliament building is located, and planned to deploy riot police on Thursday, Spanish media reported.\n\nIn a video released Wednesday, previewing his plan to return, Puigdemont lamented that he \"cannot attend freely\" and complained of \"a long persecution.\"\n\n\"That I can attend the parliament should be normal,\" he said. \"That to do so risks an arrest that would be arbitrary and illegal is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have the duty to denounce and fight.\"\n\nPuigdemont, a former journalist who was first elected to the Catalan parliament in 2006, has centered his political career on the aspiration for the wealthy northeast region to exert independence from Spain.\n\nHe was the regional president at the time of the 2017 referendum that Spain's Constitutional Court and centralized government in Madrid determined was illegal. Afterward, the Spanish government imposed direct rule and arrested his allies, while Puigdemont escaped.\n\nLast year, Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez's Socialist Party struck a contentious deal to remain in power, offering amnesty to those involved in organizing referendums in 2014 and 2017.\n\nBut the legislation has been challenged by the Supreme Court, raising questions about whether the amnesty deal would allow the pardoning of Puigdemont, who is wanted on charges of misuse of public funds.\n\nSome analysts assessed that his return reflected an attempt to restore relevance, which had waned while in exile.\n\nHe campaigned from France for the most recent regional election, in May. But pro-independence parties lost their governing majority.\n\nSalvador Illa, a Socialist, got the nod as the next regional president as a result of a deal brokered with a moderate pro-independence party. {"uri": "8265167300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:24:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:24:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:23:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/08/08/ex-catalan-leader-evades-spanish-police-on-return-after-seven-years-as-fugitive/", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader evades Spanish police on return after seven years as fugitive", "body": "Police launched a manhunt in Barcelona on Thursday for ex-Catalonia leader Carles Puigdemont, a celebrated separatist who seven years after fleeing Spain sensationally returned to the country despite an outstanding arrest warrant.\n\nMr Puigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on the day Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president.\n\nThe 61-year-old fugitive initially lived in Belgium after leaving Spain in 2017, but his most recent place of residence was not known.\n\nHe kept his travel plans secret before setting out for the wealthy Catalan region in north-eastern Spain.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, he entered an adjacent marquee before hurrying out of an exit and jumping into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Mr Puigdemont had been expected to go afterwards.\n\nOnce he had slipped away, traffic jams built up as roadside police units carried out vehicle checks across the city in an effort to catch him. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighbouring France.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that unsettled Spain for months.\n\nMr Puigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, he accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" he said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe turn of events is likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nAlberto Nunez Feijoo posted on X, formerly Twitter, that Mr Puigdemont's reappearance is an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damages Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Mr Illa to become the next regional president on Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan politicians before the vote, Mr Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty Bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favour of independence and those against it.\n\nMr Puigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in north-east Spain - a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty Bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear him and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the Bill, approved by Spain's Parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues that the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Mr Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nMr Puigdemont could be placed in pre-trial dashed out and jumped into a waiting car that sped away, an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure, said.\n\nPolice, who had set up a cordon at the nearby regional parliament where {"uri": "8264855147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "08:12:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T08:12:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T08:11:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-faces-arrest-as-supporters-cheer-his-return-to-spain/86369423", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont faces arrest as supporters cheer his return to Spain", "body": "MADRID (Reuters) - Defying an arrest warrant against him, former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont appeared in the Spanish city of Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile, as he sought to reignite a flagging independence movement.\n\nPuigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital, who had gathered near the regional parliament, waving Catalan independence flags and holding up signs showing his face.\n\nThe politician, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He is now likely to be detained over an outstanding arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\n\"That in order to do so I would risk an arbitrary and illegal detention is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have a duty to denounce and fight against,\" he said in a video posted on social media.\n\nHis arrest could delay the swearing-in of a Socialist government in Catalonia and jeopardise the national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nThe building in central Barcelona housing the regional parliament was fenced off and surrounded by officers of the Catalan police force, the Mossos d'Esquadra.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\nAmong the crowd were top officials from Junts, including the regional parliament's speaker, Josep Rull.\n\nRISK OF PRISON\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nFar-right Vox was set to hold a counter-protest outside the parliament. Its secretary general, Ignacio Garriga, said on X that \"we will not tolerate the humiliation of seeing a criminal and fugitive from justice enter parliament\".\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, was slated to kick off at 10 a.m. (0800 GMT).\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive, which has been losing support in recent years.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nPuigdemont insists the referendum was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender', 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, putting at risk his life to move the country forward,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8265181464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:33:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:33:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:32:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41452534.html", "title": "Ex-Catalan leader evades Spanish police on return after seven years as fugitive", "body": "Mr Puigdemont had previously announced his intention to be in Spain on the day Catalonia's parliament is due to swear in a new president.\n\nThe 61-year-old fugitive initially lived in Belgium after leaving Spain in 2017, but his most recent place of residence was not known.\n\nHe kept his travel plans secret before setting out for the wealthy Catalan region in north-eastern Spain.\n\nHe gave a speech in front of a large crowd of supporters in central Barcelona under the noses of police officers, who made no attempt to detain him.\n\nAfter his speech, in a cloak-and-dagger moment, he entered an adjacent marquee before hurrying out of an exit and jumping into a waiting car that sped away, according to an Associated Press photographer who witnessed his departure.\n\nAuthorities, who may have wanted to avoid confrontation with the crowd of several thousand separatist supporters, had set up a police cordon at the nearby regional parliament where Mr Puigdemont had been expected to go afterwards.\n\nOnce he had slipped away, traffic jams built up as roadside police units carried out vehicle checks across the city in an effort to catch him. Police also checked vehicles heading on highways to neighbouring France.\n\nMr Puigdemont faces charges of embezzlement for his part in an attempt to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain in 2017. As regional president and separatist party leader at the time, he was a key player in an independence referendum that was outlawed by the central government but went ahead anyway.\n\nThose events triggered a political crisis that unsettled Spain for months.\n\nMr Puigdemont's appearance in Barcelona, Catalonia's capital, and his game of cat-and-mouse with police stole the show on a day when a new government was being sworn in at the regional parliament.\n\nLocal police were deployed in a security ring around a section of the park where Catalonia's parliament building is located behind walls.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr Puigdemont, wearing a dark suit, white shirt and tie, walked with supporters to the nearby stage where he gave his speech.\n\nAddressing the crowd in the park and at times pumping his fist, he accused Spanish authorities of \"a crackdown\" on the Catalan separatist movement.\n\n\"For the last seven years we have been persecuted because we wanted to hear the voice of the Catalan people,\" he said. \"They have made being Catalan into something suspicious.\"\n\nHe added: \"All people have the right to self-determination.\"\n\nThe turn of events is likely to bring political recriminations.\n\nThe leader of the Popular Party, the main opposition to Spain's left-of-centre coalition government which has long rebuffed Catalonia's independence movement, condemned Mr Puigdemont's return.\n\nAlberto Nunez Feijoo posted on X, formerly Twitter, that Mr Puigdemont's reappearance is an \"unbearable humiliation\" that damages Spain's reputation.\n\nSpain's government encouraged a deal brokered after months of deadlock between Salvador Illa's Catalan Socialist Party (PSC) and the other main Catalan separatist party and left-wing Esquerra Republicana (ERC). That deal had ensured just enough support in Catalonia's parliament for Mr Illa to become the next regional president on Thursday.\n\nSpeaking to Catalan politicians before the vote, Mr Illa called for reconciliation and respect for Spain's controversial amnesty Bill. He vowed to govern for all Catalans after years of bitter divisions between those in favour of independence and those against it.\n\nMr Puigdemont has dedicated his career to the goal of carving out a new country in north-east Spain - a struggle which is decades-old. His largely uncompromising approach has brought political conflict with other separatist parties as well as with Spain's central government.\n\nA contentious amnesty Bill, crafted by Spain's Socialist-led coalition government, could potentially clear him and hundreds of other supporters of Catalan independence of any wrongdoing in the 2017 ballot. Spain's central government and the Constitutional Court declared at the time that the referendum was illegal.\n\nBut the Bill, approved by Spain's Parliament earlier this year, is being challenged by the Supreme Court, which argues that the pardon does not apply to embezzlement, unlike other crimes that Mr Puigdemont had previously been charged with.\n\nMr Puigdemont could be placed in pre-trial detention if he is arrested.", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "barry_hatton@irishexaminer.com", "name": "Barry Hatton", Despite a significant police presence, Puigdemont managed to address thousands of supporters in the Catalan capital and then disappeared before police could apprehend him.\n\nSpeaking from a platform near the Catalan parliament, Puigdemont energized a crowd of followers, reaffirming the independence drive that caused a political crisis in Spain seven years ago. He declared, \"Today, many thought they'd be celebrating my arrest, and thought that this punishment would dissuade us - and you. Today I came to remind them that we are still here! We are still here because we have no right to quit.\"\n\nAfter the rally, senior officials from Puigdemont's Junts party and members of the Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya led a march to the Catalan parliament, while journalists tried to spot if Puigdemont was among them. The politician is subject to an active arrest warrant and police forces are under orders to detain him if they see him.\n\n\"Despite all the efforts to do us harm, I have come here today to remind them that we are still here and that we do not have to give up,\" Puigdemont told the crowd. \"Long live Free Catalonia!\"\n\nIt is unclear where Puigdemont is now, or whether he will attempt to enter the Catalan parliament, which has been sealed off by police forces.\n\nThe former Catalan president announced his intention to return to Barcelona on Wednesday, saying he intended to be back in Barcelona for a vote on Socialist Salvador Illa becoming regional president, which would put an end to 14 years of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont intends to march to the Catalan parliament accompanied by his supporters. {"uri": "8265050164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:14:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/wanted-catalan-separatist-puigdemont-reappears-in-spain-to-rally-supporters-then-vanishes-again/86369423", "title": "Wanted Catalan separatist Puigdemont reappears in Spain to rally supporters then vanishes again", "body": "MADRID (Reuters) -Former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont defied an arrest warrant to appear at a rally in the Spanish city of Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile, and then vanished before police could arrest him.\n\nAmid a heavy police presence, Puigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital from a platform near the Catalan parliament before disappearing backstage.\n\nHe told the crowd he aimed to revive the independence drive that plunged Spain into political crisis seven years ago.\n\n\"Today, many thought they'd be celebrating my arrest, and thought that this punishment would dissuade us - and you,\" he said.\n\n\"Today I came to remind them that we are still here! We are still here because we have no right to quit.\"\n\nSenior officials of his Junts party, including parliament speaker Josep Rull, and members of the moderate separatist Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya which currently runs the regional government led a march to the Catalan parliament after the rally as journalists tried to spot whether Puigdemont was among them.\n\nA debate to swear in Socialist Salvador Illa as Catalonia\u00b4s new president, ending a decade of separatist rule, began amid confusion and speculation about Puigdemont's whereabouts and how he could have vanished in plain sight.\n\n\"We had to see how the state allowed this criminal to hold a rally,\" said Ignacio Garriga, secretary general of the far-right Vox party, told reporters outside the Catalan parliament. \"We don't understand why he hasn't been arrested yet\".\n\nA Catalan Interior Ministry spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" she said. \"I can confirm roadblocks have been set up to find him.\"\n\nPuigdemont, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He is now likely to be detained over an outstanding arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\n(Reporting by David Latona, Joan Faus, Horaci Garcia and Michael Gore; writing by David one of their own officers for his alleged involvement in helping Carles Puigdemont, the separatist leader, to escape from Barcelona following his return from a seven-year exile.\n\nThe arrested male is accused of being the owner of a vehicle which investigators believe Puigdemont used to flee the city after making a brief speech in front of thousands of supporters next to the iconic Arc de Triomf.\n\nPuigdemont, the leader of the pro-independence Junts per Catalunya party, has lived in exile ever since he fled Spain in the boot of a car seven years ago after the Spanish government launched criminal charges for his role in the 2017 independence drive.\n\nAs Catalan president, Puigdemont organised a botched independence referendum, which was deemed illegal, and unilaterally declared Catalunya as an independent state, provoking Spain's most significant political crisis since the Franco dictatorship.\n\nREAD MORE: Chaos in Spain's Catalunya: Police hunt exiled former leader Carles Puigdemont after speech near parliament declaring independence referendum legal\n\nThis morning, Puigdemont crossed the Spanish border for the first time since 2017 to coincide with the investiture debate of Salvador Illa, a Socialist ally of Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez who appears set to become the region's first pro-unity president in 14 years.\n\nFlanked by members of his Junts party, including the regional parliamentary speaker Josep Rull, Puigdemont gave a brief speech to 2,500 pro-independence supporters outside the parliament building.\n\nVideos emerged on social media of supporters clashing with counter-protesters from far-right Vox and Spanish police who launched tear gas as tensions boiled over.\n\nAfter the speech, Puigdemont quickly disappeared, prompting police to launch 'Operation Cage', an attempt to block all exits out of Barcelona so that police can arrest the former regional president.\n\nAccording to reports, police are searching for the location of a white car, the vehicle owned by the arrested Mossos officer, which they believe Puigdemont used to escape the city and likely head towards the French border.\n\nPuigdemont is currently subject to an arrest warrant regarding the alleged embezzlement of public funds whilst he was regional premier.\n\nA highly controversial amnesty law passed earlier this year by the Socialist-led government of Pedro Sanchez was deemed to not apply to the charge laid against Puigdemont, meaning any return to Spain was fraught with the risk of arrest.\n\nHowever, it appears that Puigdemont has {"uri": "8265273874", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:31:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:31:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-evades-capture-on-chaotic-return-to-spain/2214464/", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont evades capture on chaotic return to Spain", "body": "\"They thought they'd be celebrating my arrest and they thought that this punishment would dissuade us, and you,\" he said. \"Well, they are wrong.\"\n\nWhen he had finished speaking Puigdemont went backstage, after which police and media were unable to locate him.\n\nThe hunt for his whereabouts created traffic chaos in Barcelona and near the border with France as police set up roadblocks and searched car boots.\n\nPuigdemont, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since.\n\nHe faces an arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nHis supporters hope his return will rekindle enthusiasm for the Catalan independence cause, which lost support in recent years.\n\nSenior officials of Puigdemont's Junts party, including parliament speaker Josep Rull, and members of the moderate separatist Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya which currently runs the regional government led a march to the Catalan parliament after the rally.\n\nA debate to swear in Socialist Salvador Illa as Catalonia\u00b4s new president, ending a decade of separatist rule, began amid confusion and speculation about Puigdemont's whereabouts.\n\nA Catalan Interior Ministry spokesperson confirmed Puigdemont had evaded capture. \"I can confirm Puigdemont has not been detained yet,\" he said.\n\nA Supreme Court spokesperson declined to comment on Puigdemont's disappearance in Barcelona. A government spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment, nor did Puigdemont\u00b4s lawyer.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont had announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\nHis arrest could jeopardise the national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nIn the morning, a crowd of thousands had gathered near the parliament to welcome him and hear him speak.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, began an hour later.\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe embezzlement charges were related to the 2017 independence referendum ruled illegal by the Spanish courts.\n\nPuigdemont insists the vote was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender', 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, risk his life to move the country forward,\" she said.\n\n(Reporting by David Latona, Joan Faus, Horaci Garcia, {"uri": "8264825186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:52:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:52:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:51:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/08/defying-spanish-arrest-warrant-carles-puigdemont-returns-to-catalonia/", "title": "Defying Spanish Arrest Warrant, Carles Puigdemont Returns to Catalonia", "body": "Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia's separatist leader-in-exile, returned to Barcelona on Thursday after seven years, defying an arrest warrant issued by the Spanish authorities, and potentially facing arrest.\n\nMr. Puigdemont's return is a turning point in the political journey of a man who has presided over one of Spain's most fraught political issues -- the independence bid of the prosperous northeastern region of Catalonia.\n\nWrapped in red and yellow Catalan flags, pro-independence supporters gathered by Barcelona's Arc de Triomf, a towering brick memorial arch, to welcome him, chanting \"Puigdemont is our president,\" and hoping his comeback would energize a movement whose popularity has been dwindling.\n\n\"We have been persecuted for seven years for wanting to hear the voice of the people of Catalonia\" Mr. Puigdemont said from a stage below the arch as people waved his photos, banners and tote bags bearing his name.\n\nIn 2017, Mr. Puigdemont drove the independence referendum that provoked Spain's most severe constitutional crisis in decades. His hard-line separatist party, Together for Catalonia, played the kingmaker in last year's Spanish election, obtaining in return an amnesty law for alleged crimes linked to the 2017 failed bid for independence. The law, which passed earlier this year, partly paved the way for Mr. Puigdemont's return.\n\nIt is still unclear whether Mr. Puigdemont will be detained and whether the amnesty law, which would potentially affect many separatists, will apply to him. From the start, judges have criticized the amnesty law, saying that it infringes on the separation of powers.\n\nMr. Puigdemont is also still facing trial on accusations of embezzlement, even though judges dropped the terrorism investigation against him.\n\nWhat is for sure, experts say, is that his return is a last-ditch effort to remain relevant in Spain and in Catalonia, where pro-independence support has dwindled and where for the first time in decades separatist parties did not win an outright majority in Parliament in May.\n\nThe Republican Left of Catalonia -- another, more moderate separatist party -- has backed a Socialist leader as the regional government's next president, and experts said Mr. Puigdemont was hoping his return could push the party to pull from the coalition, and potentially have new elections.\n\n\"It's Mr. Puigdemont's last dance,\" said Ignacio Lago, a professor of political science at Pompeu Fabra University in Barcelona.\n\nBefore his arrival, Mr. Puigdemont, formerly a mayor from the Spanish hinterland, said that he was aware of his likely arrest, but that it was the only solution to what he called a democratic crisis in Spain. During his time in exile, Mr. Puigdemont was summoned by the authorities in several European countries and detained in Italy and Germany.\n\nHe also continued to insist on \"the necessity of independence as the only alternative\" for the \"survival of Catalonia.\"\n\nMr. Puigdemont was the president of the Catalan government when a 2017 referendum in defiance of the Spanish government shook the country, and he issued a sort of unilateral declaration of independence. Amid unrest and police crackdown, two nationalist movements -- Spanish and Catalan -- came at odds, digging a deep fissure within the country.\n\nPro-independence Catalans never saw their dream of living in an independent state come so near. Other Spaniards saw an existential threat to their nationhood, reviving among conservatives the Spanish nationalism that was considered taboo in the aftermath of the Francisco Franco dictatorship, and bolstering right-wing hard-liners.\n\nEven as his 2017 secessionist bid failed, and after years in self-imposed exile in Belgium, Mr. Puigdemont returned to be relevant when the Spanish prime minister sought his support last year and offered the polarizing amnesty law in return.\n\nExperts said the amnesty law made it harder for Mr. Puigdemont to remain abroad.\n\n\"The amnesty law has created the conditions for him to return,\" said Pablo Sim\u00f3n, a political scientist at Carlos III University in Madrid. \"Returning is the only thing he can do in order to continue to play the victim.\"\n\nThe secessionist parties have for years accused judges of being politically motivated, and in a letter he wrote on Saturday, Mr. Puigdemont said that his return would provide more evidence that \"amnesties do not amnesty,\" and that \"there are judges willing to disobey the law.\"\n\nThe grievances of the pro-independence movement are centuries-old and deep rooted. They were bolstered by the victory of independence parties in the region's Parliament and kept alive by a severe clampdown by the Spanish government.\n\nCatalans are evenly divided between pro-and anti-independence feelings, with both sides of the debate ranging from 40 to 50 percent of popular support in recent years. But in since 2017, pro-independence sentiment has declined, partly because of disillusionment with the separatist movements, and because global events, including the pandemic, have given Catalans other things to worry about, and perhaps a reason to stick together.\n\nWitnessing all of this, Mr. Mr. Puigdemont decided to \"press the nuclear button\" by returning to Spain, said Mr. Sim\u00f3n, the political analyst. \"He shot his last bullet.\"", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": His speech reignited enthusiasm for Catalan independence. Puigdemont then vanished, leading to a frantic police search. His return risks jeopardizing Spain's government alliance.\n\nCarles Puigdemont, the former Catalan separatist leader, defied an arrest warrant to make a public appearance in Barcelona after seven years in self-imposed exile. His return has rekindled enthusiasm for the Catalan independence movement, which has waned in recent years.\n\nSpeaking to a crowd of thousands, Puigdemont announced his aim to revive the independence drive that led to Spain's political crisis in 2017. He vanished soon after his speech, prompting a police search throughout Barcelona and nearby areas.\n\nPuigdemont faces charges of alleged embezzlement, which he denies. {"uri": "8264966948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "09:24:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T09:24:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:22:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/catalan-separatist-puigdemont-faces-arrest-as-supporters-cheer-his-return-to-spain/article_d67cfa22-7c1d-53ee-8508-e83d52ce9b0d.html", "title": "Catalan separatist Puigdemont faces arrest as supporters cheer his return to Spain", "body": "The hemicycle of the Catalonia Regional Parliament is seen empty, a day before the investiture debate of Catalonia to elect a new leader, in Barcelona, Spain, August 7, 2024. REUTERS/Jon Nazca\n\nBy Joan Faus\n\nMADRID (Reuters) - Defying an arrest warrant against him, former Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont appeared in the Spanish city of Barcelona on Thursday after seven years of self-imposed exile, as he sought to reignite a flagging independence movement.\n\nPuigdemont spoke to a crowd of thousands of followers in the Catalan capital, who had gathered near the regional parliament, waving Catalan independence flags and holding up signs showing his face.\n\nThe politician, 61, fled to Belgium seven years ago after a failed secession bid and has been living in exile ever since. He is now likely to be detained over an outstanding arrest warrant for alleged embezzlement, which he denies.\n\nOn Wednesday, Puigdemont announced he had started his \"return trip from exile\", saying he remained committed to attending Thursday's session of the regional parliament, which is sitting to swear in the region's new leader following an election in May, in which Puigdemont's Junts party finished second.\n\n\"That in order to do so I would risk an arbitrary and illegal detention is evidence of the democratic anomaly that we have a duty to denounce and fight against,\" he said in a video posted on social media.\n\nHis arrest could delay the swearing-in of a Socialist government in Catalonia and jeopardise the national government\u00b4s fragile alliance with Junts, on which it relies for legislative support.\n\nThe building in central Barcelona housing the regional parliament was fenced off and surrounded by officers of the Catalan police force, the Mossos d'Esquadra.\n\nSeveral police vans were located nearby after radical protest group CDR called on its members to attend the gathering.\n\nAmong the crowd were top officials from Junts, including the regional parliament's speaker, Josep Rull.\n\nRISK OF PRISON\n\n\"It represents the return of a symbol,\" said Xavier Vizcaino, 63, who was wrapped in an independence flag.\n\nGiven the risk of imprisonment, Vizcaino said he was unclear of Puigdemont's intentions but hoped his return would build momentum towards independence.\n\n\"I hope it is a stimulus that helps the movement recover energy and efforts,\" he said. \"I want to believe there is a well structured plan behind his return.\"\n\nFar-right Vox was set to hold a counter-protest outside the parliament. Its secretary general, Ignacio Garriga, said on X that \"we will not tolerate the humiliation of seeing a criminal and fugitive from justice enter parliament\".\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, was slated to kick off at 10 a.m. (0800 GMT).\n\nThe Socialists hope taking control in Catalonia after a decade of separatist rule will turn the page on the independence drive, which has been losing support in recent years.\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nPuigdemont insists the referendum was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\nWearing a T-shirt and waving a flag with Puigdemont's face and the motto 'No surrender', 41-year-old Susana Masnou described his return as an act of \"democratic disobedience\" to make sure the amnesty law applies to him.\n\n\"He is a very brave man, with convictions, putting at risk his life to move the country forward,\" she said.\n\n(Reporting by David Latona, Joan Faus, Horaci Garcia and Michael Gore; writing by David Latona and Charlie Devereux; editing by Sandra Maler and Sharon Singleton)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [], Supporters formed a human barrier around him. The politician is subject to an active arrest warrant and police forces are under orders to detain him if they see him.\n\n\"Despite all the efforts to do us harm, I have come here today to remind them that we are still here and that we do not have to give up,\" Puigdemont told the crowd. \"Long live Free Catalonia!\"\n\nIt is unclear where Puigdemont is now, or whether he will attempt to enter the Catalan parliament, which has been sealed off by police forces.\n\nThe former Catalan president announced his intention to return to Barcelona on Wednesday, saying he intended to be back in Barcelona for a vote on Socialist Salvador Illa becoming regional president, which would put an end to 14 years of separatist governments.\n\nPuigdemont intends to march to the Catalan parliament accompanied by his supporters. Police forces have sealed off the building and are guarding the entrances.\n\nExpectation was high ahead of Puigdemont's promised appearance. {"uri": "8265364211", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "13:26:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T13:26:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T13:25:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://sarajevotimes.com/a-state-of-siege-in-barcelona-the-police-are-looking-for-puigdemont-in-the-city/", "title": "A State of Siege in Barcelona, the Police are looking for Puigdemont in the City - Sarajevo Times", "body": "After the former leader of the Catalan separatists, Carles Puigdemont, appeared in Barcelona after seven years, gave a speech and disappeared into the crowd, complete chaos arose in Catalonia.\n\nNamely, after Puigdemont appeared on the territory of Catalonia, that is, Spain, the court activated a warrant for his arrest.\n\nIn the meantime, he gave a speech and disappeared from the stage with his associates. Although he was expected to attend the session of the Catalan parliament where the new president is elected, Puigdemont was not seen in the hall, and the autonomous police of Catalonia Mossos d'Esquadra activated the \"Cage\" police operation and activated the tracking devices to locate Puigdemont.\n\nSEVEN YEARS OUTSIDE OF SPAIN\n\nCarles Puigdemont caused chaos after returning to Catalonia: Gave a speech in Barcelona and then disappeared into the crowd\n\n\"Catalan police planned to arrest Puigdemont before the plenary session. Other Catalan separatist parties and civil society groups said they would also attend.\n\nFar-right Vox was set to hold a counter-protest outside the parliament. Its secretary general, Ignacio Garriga, said on X that \"we will not tolerate the humiliation of seeing a criminal and fugitive from justice enter parliament\".\n\nThe vote to invest Socialist Salvador Illa, who will be backed by the left-wing separatist ERC party after a bilateral deal last week, is slated to kick off at 10 a.m. (0800 GMT).\n\nThe Spanish parliament passed an amnesty law in May pardoning those involved in the failed 2017 secession bid, but the Supreme Court upheld arrest warrants for Puigdemont and two others who were also charged with embezzlement, ruling that the amnesty law does not apply to them.\n\nThe court said the three obtained personal gain by charging the expenses of holding the independence referendum deemed illegal by the Spanish judiciary to the regional treasury, a move he described as not being in the public interest.\n\nPuigdemont insists the referendum was not illegal and so the charges linked to it have no basis.\n\n(Reporting by David {"uri": "2024-08-444359526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:00:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.catalannews.com/politics/item/crucial-week-begins-for-catalan-presidency-in-parliament-", "title": "Crucial week begins for Catalan presidency in parliament", "body": "Josep Rull, the speaker of the Catalan parliament, will hold talks on Tuesday with all the parties ahead of the presidential investiture debate for the Socialist candidate Salvador Illa.\n\nIlla is expected to have enough support from lawmakers in the chamber after striking deals with pro-independence Esquerra Republicana, a deal endorsed by party members, as well as with left-wing Comuns Sumar.\n\nThe investiture debate and the voting for the candidate could take place on Thursday.\n\nIt remains to be seen, however, what the youth representative of Esquerra, MP Mar Besses, will do, as her parliamentary vote in any investiture debate will be decided by an internal vote among members of the party's youth branch.\n\nIn that case, Illa would not be elected with an absolute majority (at least 68 MPs voting in favor). Two days later, another investiture debate would take place where the Socialist would need a simple majority (more yes votes than no). However, this would only be possible with the abstention of another MP from another party.\n\nIt is not yet known how former president Carles Puigdemont's expected return to Catalonia would affect the debate on Thursday.\n\nDuring the election campaign and the following months, Puigdemont stated repeatedly that he would attend the investiture debate in person, despite the fact that he could get arrested.\n\nParliament speaker Rull has expressed on various occasions that if Carles Puigdemont makes it inside of the Parliament, he would defend the inviolability of the chamber and regulate police access to the building.\n\nThere has been speculation that if Puigdemont returns and is arrested, the investiture debate could be suspended by Josep Rull.\n\nRegarding the possible arrest, Marta Rovira, Esquerra's secretary general, said that in this scenario \"the leadership of the party will have to meet and make a decision\" about withdrawing Esquerra's support for the Socialists.\n\nJ\u00e9ssica Albiach, the leader of Comuns Sumar in Catalonia, has also expressed that if Puigdemont is arrested they are in favor of postponing the debate \"a few days or a week.\"\n\nOn June 11, the amnesty law was published in Spain's Official Gazette (BOE) officially coming into effect.\n\nSince then, more than 80 people have benefited from it, but not Carles Puigdemont.\n\nThe law granted amnesty for the crime of disobedience for which the independence leaders were convicted, but Spain's Supreme Court ruled that the crime of misuse of public funds is not included in the amnesty law for the Catalan pro-independence movement.\n\nAs a result, arrest warrants are still in force for former president Carles Puigdemont, along with other exiled pro-independence leaders Toni Com\u00edn and Lluis Puig.\n\nIn addition, Carles Puigdemont is also investigated for the alleged Russian plot to support Catalan independence, the Volhov case. {"uri": "2024-08-447732245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:13:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:13:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:05:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3045440-catalan-leader-puigdemont-returns-to-barcelona-after-years-in-exile", "title": "Catalan Leader Puigdemont Returns to Barcelona After Years in Exile", "body": "After seven years of self-imposed exile, Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont made a public appearance in Barcelona. Addressing supporters at the Arc de Triomf, Puigdemont declared the ongoing commitment to their cause, despite facing an arrest warrant.\n\nCatalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont made a surprising appearance in Barcelona on Thursday, marking his return after seven years of self-imposed exile. Despite a pending arrest warrant, Puigdemont addressed a crowd of supporters at the Arc de Triomf monument, according to a Reuters witness.\n\nSurrounded by officials of his hardline separatist party Junts, Puigdemont climbed onto a stage and spoke to thousands of enthusiastic followers in Catalan. 'I've come today to remind you that we're still here,' he proclaimed, signaling the resilience of their movement.\n\nNotably, Puigdemont's arrival was unimpeded by law enforcement, highlighting a significant moment in the ongoing separatist struggle in Catalonia.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
